ENTRY:F:Unigine.LightVoxelProbe.BLEND_ADDITIVE
DESC:The additive mode of light blending. This option offers more flexibility in lighting control. you can use it to blend lighting of several Voxel Probes together and control them separately (e.g. make a separate Voxel Probe for an indoor emissive light source and blend it with another Voxel Probe with lighting baked from the sky, having the ability to enable and disable them separately). Voxel probes with additive blending enabled cannot be used to add lighting details (e.g. creating a small high-detail Voxel Probe inside a large low-detail one). Such probes do not replace each other, as they are blended instead.
-

DESC:The multiplicative mode of light blending.

ENTRY:F:Unigine.LightWorld.SCATTERING_NONE

ENTRY:F:Unigine.LightWorld.SCATTERING_SUN

ENTRY:F:Unigine.LightWorld.SHADOW_CASCADE_MODE_STATIC
DESC:Static shadow cascade generation mode. In this mode shadow cascades are built and baked relative to the light source's position. This mode is suitable as a performance optimization technique for small-area ArchViz projects where shadow cascades can be divided into 2 sections: walkable area with high-resolution shadows (as they're observed closely) and non-walkable area with low-resolution shadows (as they're observed from a distance). Changing the time of day is not available in this mode, as shadow cascades are baked.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.LightWorld.SHADOW_CASCADE_MODE_DYNAMIC
DESC:Dynamic shadow cascade generation mode. In this mode shadow cascades are built dynamically relative to the camera's position. All shadows are calculated dynamically making it possible to change the time of day (day-night cycle).
-

ENTRY:M:Unigine.LoadingScreen.render(int)
DESC:Renders a custom loading screen in a given progress state. Use this function in a loop to create a gradual change between the initial (upper opaque part) and the final states (bottom transparent part) of the loading screen texture.
PARAMS:progress:Progress of alpha blending between 2 screens stored in the texture. The value in range [0;100] sets an alpha channel threshold, according to which pixels from the initial (opaque) or final (transparent) screen in the texture are rendered. By the value of 0, the initial screen is loaded. By the value of 100, the final screen is loaded.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.LoadingScreen.render(int,char)
DESC:Renders a custom loading screen in a given progress state and prints a given message. Use this function in a loop to create a gradual change between the initial (upper opaque part) and the final states (bottom transparent part) of the loading screen texture, while printing a custom loading stage.
PARAMS:progress:Progress of alpha blending between 2 loading screens stored in the texture. The value in range [0;100] sets an alpha channel threshold, according to which pixels from the initial (opaque) or final (transparent) loading screen in the texture are rendered. By the value of 0, the initial screen is loaded. By the value of 100, the final screen is loaded. | message:message to print representing the loading stage.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.WorldLogic.updateSyncThread(int,int)
DESC:Engine calls this function before the update() and the postUpdate(). Limitations: you should not create or modify nodes unless you're absolutely sure that no other thread can do the same. This function is called size times each frame and executed in parallel threads. Each time the function is called with an index in the range [0; size), i.e.: 0, 1, ..., size-1. This function blocks the Main Thread until all size calls are completed. Unlike the SyncThread() this function has got less time for execution, but it is more secure and is suitable for complex calculations to be applied to the current node.
PARAMS:id:Index of the current thread, that called this function in the [0; size) range. | size:Number of threads for execution. The function is called size times each frame and executed in parallel threads. Each time the function is called with an index in the range [0; size), i.e.: 0, 1, ..., size-1.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.WorldLogic.updateAsyncThread(int,int)
DESC:Engine calls this function before the execution of all updateSyncThread() functions. Like the updateSyncThread() it is called size times each frame and executed in parallel with user's postUpdate() and updatePhysics() functions, but does not block the Main Thread until the Engine reaches the doSwap() stage (similar to the updatePhysics() function). This function is the smoothest and does not cause spikes, it has a lot of time for execution. But it also has a lot of limitations. It is suitable for certain heavy resource-consuming calculations calculations that should be performed each frame, such as pathfinding, generation of procedural textures, and so on.
PARAMS:id:Index of the current thread, that called this function in the [0; size) range. | size:Number of threads for execution. The function is called size times each frame and executed in parallel threads. Each time the function is called with an index in the range [0; size), i.e.: 0, 1, ..., size-1.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.WorldLogic.postUpdate
DESC:Engine calls this function before rendering each render frame. You can correct behavior after the state of the node has been updated. Similar to the world script's postUpdate() function.
RETURNS:Returns 1 if there were no errors; otherwise, 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.WorldLogic.updatePhysics
DESC:Engine calls this function before updating each physics frame. This function is used to control physics in your application. The engine calls updatePhysics() with the fixed rate (60 times per second by default) regardless of the fps number. Similar to the world script's updatePhysics() function.
RETURNS:Returns 1 if there were no errors; otherwise, 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.WorldLogic.swap
DESC:Engine calls this function after the following processes are completed: rendering (CPU portion), physics calculations and pathfinding, GUI rendering, and all Async threads. The function is designed to operate with the results of the updateAsyncThread() method — all other methods (threads) have already been performed and are idle. After this function, only two actions occur: All objects that are queued for deletion are deleted. Profiler is updated. This function is similar to the world script's swap() function.
RETURNS:Returns 1 if there were no errors; otherwise, 0.
-

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Material.runExpression(char,int,int,int)
DESC:Runs the material's expression with the specified name. An expression is a reference to a file containing code in UnigineScript, that can generate various elements used in the material (e.g., textures, texture arrays, unstructured buffers, etc.) or contain other logic. Expressions can be defined in the *.basemat file as follows: An example of expression.usc code: To execute this expression the following code can be used: Expressions can be executed only for base materials.
PARAMS:name:Expression name. Expression with this name must be defined in the material declaration (*.basemat file). | w:Width, e.g. if a texture or a structured buffer is generated by the expression. | h:Height, e.g. if a texture or a structured buffer is generated by the expression. | d:Depth, e.g. if a 3D Texture, 2D array or a structured buffer is generated by the expression.
RETURNS:true if the specified expression is executed successfully; otherwise, false.
-

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Material.getShaderAsync(Render::PASS,int)
DESC:Returns the rendering shader for the specified rendering pass and node type: If the shader has been compiled previously, the function will return it immediately. If the shader hasn't been compiled yet, the function will initiate its asynchronous compilation in another thread and return the successfully compiled shader. The function will keep returning nullptr until the shader is compiled. To compile the shader asynchronously, enable the asynchronous compilation mode. Otherwise, the function will work the same as getShaderForce().
PARAMS:pass:Rendering pass number in range [0;NUM_PASSES) (one of the PASS_* variables). | node:Node type.
RETURNS:Shader for the specified rendering pass and node type, if compiled successfully. Otherwise, nullptr.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Material.getShaderAsync(Render::PASS)
DESC:Returns the rendering shader for the specified rendering pass: If the shader has been compiled previously, the function will return it immediately. If the shader hasn't been compiled yet, the function will initiate its asynchronous compilation in another thread and return the successfully compiled shader. The function will keep returning nullptr until the shader is compiled. To compile the shader asynchronously, enable the asynchronous compilation mode. Otherwise, the function will work the same as getShaderForce().
PARAMS:pass:Rendering pass number in range [0;NUM_PASSES) (one of the PASS_* variables).
RETURNS:Shader for the specified rendering pass, if compiled successfully. Otherwise, nullptr.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Material.getShaderAsync(char,int)
DESC:Returns the rendering shader for the specified rendering pass and node type: If the shader has been compiled previously, the function will return it immediately. If the shader hasn't been compiled yet, the function will initiate its asynchronous compilation in another thread and return the successfully compiled shader. The function will keep returning nullptr until the shader is compiled. To compile the shader asynchronously, enable the asynchronous compilation mode. Otherwise, the function will work the same as getShaderForce().
PARAMS:pass:Rendering pass name. One of the following:wireframevisualizer_soliddeferredauxiliaryemissionreflectionrefractiontransparent_blurambientlight_voxel_probelight_environment_probelight_omnilight_projlight_worldshadowdepth_pre_passpostobject_post | node:Node type.
RETURNS:Shader for the specified rendering pass and node type, if compiled successfully. Otherwise, nullptr.
-

DESC:Returns the rendering shader for the specified rendering pass: If the shader has been compiled previously, the function will return it immediately. If the shader hasn't been compiled yet, the function will initiate its asynchronous compilation in another thread and return the successfully compiled shader. The function will keep returning nullptr until the shader is compiled. To compile the shader asynchronously, enable the asynchronous compilation mode. Otherwise, the function will work the same as getShaderForce().
PARAMS:pass:Rendering pass name. One of the following:wireframevisualizer_soliddeferredauxiliaryemissionreflectionrefractiontransparent_blurambientlight_voxel_probelight_environment_probelight_omnilight_projlight_worldshadowdepth_pre_passpostobject_post

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Material.getShaderForce(Render::PASS,int)
DESC:Returns the rendering shader for the specified rendering pass and node type: If the shader has been compiled previously, the function will return it immediately. If the shader hasn't been compiled yet, the function will immediately compile and return it. The function causes a spike because it compiles the shader in the current thread.
PARAMS:pass:Rendering pass number in range [0;NUM_PASSES) (one of the PASS_* variables). | node:Node type.
RETURNS:Shader for the specified rendering pass and node type, if compiled successfully. Otherwise, nullptr.
-

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Material.createShaderForce(Render::PASS,Node::TYPE)
DESC:Compiles shader combination for the given rendering pass and node type. Shaders are compiled immediately, which may cause spikes, therefore this method is recommended only for critical cases, where doesn't ensure a satisfying result.
PARAMS:pass:Rendering pass number in range [0;NUM_PASSES) (one of the PASS_* variables). | node_type:Node type.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Material.createShaderAsync(Render::PASS,Node::TYPE)
DESC:Compiles shader combination for the given rendering pass and node type. Shaders are compiled asynchronously, which ensures smooth performance without spikes and is suitable for most cases. For the shaders that requre to be compiled immediately, use .
PARAMS:pass:Rendering pass number in range [0;NUM_PASSES) (one of the PASS_* variables). | node_type:Node type.

ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_SSR
DESC:Texture of this type stores SSR (Screen Space Reflections) data.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_CURVATURE
DESC:Texture used for the Screen-Space Dirt effect (SSDirt).
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_MIN_DISTANCE
DESC:Texture of this type stores data from the minimum distance buffer.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_DOF_MASK
DESC:Texture of this type stores a DoF (Depth of Field) mask.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_AUTO_EXPOSURE
DESC:An RG16F texture that stores intensity of the exposure (R) and luminance (G).
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_AUTO_WHITE_BALANCE
DESC:Auto white balance texture (RGB16F), color values.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_SCREEN_COLOR
DESC:Texture of this type stores screen color data and can be used for post effects.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_SCREEN_COLOR_OLD
DESC:Texture of this type stores Color Old (previous frame) data.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_SCREEN_COLOR_OLD_REPROJECTION
DESC:Texture of this type stores Color Old (previous frame) Reprojection data.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_NORMAL_UNPACK
DESC:a texture that stores unpacked normals. Available for the following post-effects: SSR, SSGI, SSRTGI, Shadows screen space.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_CURRENT_DEPTH
DESC:Texture of this type stores current depth data for all geometry on the scene.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_OPACITY_DEPTH
DESC:Texture of this type stores depth data for opacity geometry and can be used for soft particles and volumetrics.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_LINEAR_DEPTH
DESC:Texture of this type stores linear depth data.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_OPACITY_DEPTH_REPROJECTION_BACK
DESC:Texture of this type stores depth data for opaque geometry reprojected from the previous frame.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_LIGHT_IMAGE
DESC:Texture of this type stores the light values provided by projected light sources.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_LIGHT_SHADOW_DEPTH
DESC:Texture of this type stores depth values (used to render shadows).
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_LIGHT_SHADOW_COLOR
DESC:Texture of this type (RG) stores depth (G-channel) and transparency (R-channel) values (used to render translucent shadows).
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_TRANSPARENT_ENVIRONMENT
DESC:An RGBA16F texture that stores environment probes and environment rendered on transparent objects. Available only for transparent materials rendered in the forward pass when Multiple environment probes are enabled.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_REFLECTION_2D
DESC:Texture of this type stores reflection values (used to render 2D reflections).
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_REFLECTION_CUBE
DESC:Texture of this type stores reflection values (used to render cube-mapped reflections).
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_SCATTERING_SKY_LUT
DESC:Texture of this type stores sky scattering LUT data.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_WBUFFER_CONSTANT_ID
DESC:Constant texture, R32U. A texture of this type stores the ID value of the water mesh which is used to load the corresponding textures and parameters for it.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_WBUFFER_DIFFUSE
DESC:Diffuse texture. The diffuse color of the water is black, and diffuse texture is necessary for decals, that will be displayed over the water surface.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_WBUFFER_NORMAL
DESC:Normal texture stores normal data for lighting, and alpha channel stores mesh transparency values (it can be used for soft intersections with water geometry).
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_WBUFFER_FOAM
DESC:Water foam texture, RG8. It is used to create the procedural foam mask. The mask shows where the foam will be depicted.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_WBUFFER_SS_ENVIRONMENT
DESC:An RGBA16 underwater fog texture that stores water bottom coloring values (RGB) and fog transparency (A).
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_WBUFFER_WU_MASK
DESC:Underwater mask texture, RGB8. Underwater mask is used only for Global water, since water mesh doesn't have an underwater mode.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_WBUFFER_PLANAR_REFLECTION
DESC:Water dynamic planar reflection texture, RGBA16F.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_CLOUDS_SCREEN
DESC:An RGBA16F texture into which clouds are rendered.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_CLOUDS_STATIC_COVERAGE
DESC:Texture of this type stores clouds static coverage data.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_CLOUDS_REGION_MASK
DESC:A single-channel texture used to define areas for the layer where the clouds are to be rendered and where they shouldn't (for regional weather).
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_CLOUDS_DYNAMIC_COVERAGE
DESC:Texture of this type stores clouds dynamic coverage data.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_TERRAIN_GLOBAL_DEPTH
DESC:Texture storing depth data for the Global Terrain.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_TERRAIN_GLOBAL_FLAT_POSITION
DESC:Texture storing geodetic flat positions for the Global Terrain.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_FIELD_HEIGHT_ARRAY
DESC:A heightmap texture is used to create an additional height displacement for water surface. Field Height textures are rendered in a 2D array of R16F or R32F textures (depends on settings). All Field Height textures are packed into 2D array to pass the data to the shader.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_FIELD_SHORELINE_ARRAY
DESC:A field shoreline texture. All Field Shoreline textures are packed into 2D array (of RGBA8) to pass the data to the shader.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_DECAL_DEPTH
DESC:Texture of this type stores depth data for decals.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_DECAL_ALBEDO
DESC:Texture of this type stores albedo color data for decals.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_DECAL_NORMAL
DESC:Texture of this type stores normal data for decals.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_DECAL_SHADING
DESC:Texture of this type stores shading data for decals.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TEXTURE_SOURCE_CUSTOM
DESC:Custom user texture.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TRANSPARENT_NONE
DESC:Opaque material (non-transparent), doesn't use blend func.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TRANSPARENT_ALPHA_TEST
DESC:Transparent material which uses alpha test.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TRANSPARENT_BLEND
DESC:Transparent material which is rendered in forward pass, uses blend func.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.TRANSPARENT_WATER
DESC:Transparent material which is rendered in water pass.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.OPTION_TRANSPARENT
DESC:The material is transparent.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.OPTION_ORDER
DESC:Sort order used when rendering transparent objects (objects that are assigned materials with the Alpha Blend, Additive, and Multiplicative presets). Objects with the lowest order numbers are rendered first, and objects with the highest order numbers are rendered last.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.OPTION_SHADOW_MASK
DESC:Shadow mask used to control shadows cast by an object lit by light sources. A surface, having this material assigned, casts shadows from a light source, if its surface and material shadow masks match the light mask of a light source (one bit at least).
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.OPTION_VIEWPORT_MASK
DESC:Viewport mask of the material. A surface, having this material assigned, is rendered into a viewport, if its surface and material viewport masks match the viewport mask of the camera (one bit at least).
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.OPTION_BLEND_SRC
DESC:Blend function for the Src image. Defines combination of an image with the background creating an appearance of partial or full transparency.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.OPTION_BLEND_DEST
DESC:Blend function for the Dest image. Defines combination of an image with the background creating an appearance of partial or full transparency.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.OPTION_DEPTH_TEST
DESC:Depth testing for the material. This can be used to make the object visible, when occluded by other objects (e.g. a character behind a wall).
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.OPTION_TWO_SIDED
DESC:The material has two sides, i.e. polygons, to which the material is applied, are rendered two times per lighting pass for the material to be seen from the other side.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.OPTION_CAST_PROJ_OMNI_SHADOW
DESC:The material casts shadow when lit by the omni and projected light sources.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.OPTION_CAST_WORLD_SHADOW
DESC:The material casts shadow when lit by the global light source.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.OPTION_OVERLAP
DESC:Rendering polygons, to which the material is applied, on the top of the render, overlapping any other images. This can be used for UI elements.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Material.OPTION_DEPTH_PRE_PASS
DESC:Depth pre-pass rendering, i.e. an additional depth buffer rendering pass is performed for the material in the beginning of the rendering sequence. Performed only for alpha test and complex materials.
-

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.bezier(float,float,float)
DESC:Calculates the value of a cubic Bezier function for t = time. A cubic Bezier curve is represented by 4 points. Po is the start point, P1 and P2 are control points 1 and 2 and P3 is the end point. The start and end point denote the beginning and end points of the path and the control points determine how the path moves from the start to the finish. As can be seen from the image, the only variable changing is t which determines how far the path has progressed from P0 to P3. Cubic Bezier curves are used as timing functions particularly for keyframe interpolation.
PARAMS:times:Coordinates of the four points of the curve along the horizontal T (times) axis in the range [0.0f, 1.0f]. | values:Coordinates of the four points of the curve along the vertical V (values) axis in the range [0.0f, 1.0f]. | time:Time in the range [0, 1], for which the value of the Bezier function is to be calculated.
RETURNS:Value of the Bezier function.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.bezier(float,double,float)
DESC:Calculates the value of a cubic Bezier function for t = time. A cubic Bezier curve is represented by 4 points. Po is the start point, P1 and P2 are control points 1 and 2 and P3 is the end point. The start and end point denote the beginning and end points of the path and the control points determine how the path moves from the start to the finish. As can be seen from the image, the only variable changing is t which determines how far the path has progressed from P0 to P3. Cubic Bezier curves are used as timing functions particularly for keyframe interpolation.
PARAMS:times:Coordinates of the four points of the curve along the horizontal T (times) axis in the range [0.0f, 1.0f]. | values:Coordinates of the four points of the curve along the vertical V (values) axis in the range [0.0f, 1.0f]. | time:Time in the range [0, 1], for which the value of the Bezier function is to be calculated.
RETURNS:Value of the Bezier function.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.distance(Unigine.vec2,Unigine.vec2)
DESC:Calculates the distance between the two given vectors. The distance is calculated as: length(v0 - v1).
PARAMS:v0:First vector. | v1:Second vector.
RETURNS:Distance between the two given vectors.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.distance(Unigine.vec3,Unigine.vec3)

RETURNS:Distance between the two given vectors.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.distance2(Unigine.vec2,Unigine.vec2)
DESC:Calculates the squared distance between the two given vectors. The squared distance is calculated as: length2(v0 - v1). This method is much faster than distance() - the calculation is basically the same only without the slow Sqrt call. If you simply want to compare distances, then it is faster to compare squared distances against the squares of distances as the comparison gives the same result.
PARAMS:v0:First vector. | v1:Second vector.
RETURNS:Squared distance between the two given vectors.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.distance2(Unigine.dvec2,Unigine.dvec2)
DESC:Calculates the squared distance between the two given vectors. The squared distance is calculated as: length2(v0 - v1). This method is much faster than distance() - the calculation is basically the same only without the slow Sqrt call. If you simply want to compare distances, then it is faster to compare squared distances against the squares of distances as the comparison gives the same result.
PARAMS:v0:First vector. | v1:Second vector.
RETURNS:Squared distance between the two given vectors.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.distance2(Unigine.vec3,Unigine.vec3)

PARAMS:v0:First vector. | v1:Second vector.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.getAngle(Unigine.quat,Unigine.quat)
DESC:Returns the angle (in degrees) between the given first and second quaternions. The angle returned is the unsigned acute angle between the two quaternions. This means the smaller of the two possible angles is used.
PARAMS:q0:First quaternion (from which the angular difference is measured). | q1:Second quaternion (to which the angular difference is measured).
RETURNS:Angle between the given quaternions, in degrees within the range [0.0; 180.0].
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.getAngle(Unigine.vec3,Unigine.vec3)
DESC:Returns the angle (in degrees) between the given first and second vectors. The angle returned is the unsigned acute angle between the two vectors. This means the smaller of the two possible angles is used.
PARAMS:v0:First vector (from which the angular difference is measured). | v1:Second vector (to which the angular difference is measured).
RETURNS:Angle between the given vectors, in degrees within the range [0.0; 180.0].
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.getAngle(Unigine.vec3,Unigine.vec3,Unigine.vec3)
DESC:Returns the signed angle (in degrees) between the given first and second vectors relative to the specified "up" vector.
PARAMS:v0:First vector (from which the angular difference is measured). | v1:Second vector (to which the angular difference is measured). | up:Up vector, around which the other two vectors are rotated.
RETURNS:Angle between the given vectors, in degrees within the range [-180.0; 180.0].
-

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.inverseLerp(float,float,float)
DESC:Returns the value calculated according to the following formula: (v - v0) / (v1 - v0) clamped within 0.0f and 1.0f.
PARAMS:v0:The value specifying the beginning of the interval. | v1:The value specifying the ending of the interval. | v:The value within the specified interval.
RETURNS:Coefficient of the value within a specified interval.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.inverseLerp(double,double,double)
DESC:Returns the value calculated according to the following formula: (v - v0) / (v1 - v0) clamped within 0.0 and 1.0.
PARAMS:v0:The value specifying the beginning of the interval. | v1:The value specifying the ending of the interval. | v:The value within the specified interval.
RETURNS:Coefficient of the value within a specified interval.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.inverseLerp(Unigine.vec2,Unigine.vec2,Unigine.vec2)
DESC:Returns the vector with two float values calculated according to the following formula: (v - v0) / (v1 - v0) clamped within 0.0f and 1.0f.
PARAMS:v0:Vector storing the values that specify the beginnings of the intervals. | v1:Vector storing the values that specify the endings of the intervals. | v:The values within the specified intervals.
RETURNS:Coefficients of the values within a specified intervals.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.inverseLerp(Unigine.vec3,Unigine.vec3,Unigine.vec3)
DESC:Returns the vector with three float values calculated according to the following formula: (v - v0) / (v1 - v0) clamped within 0.0f and 1.0f.
PARAMS:v0:Vector storing the values that specify the beginnings of the intervals. | v1:Vector storing the values that specify the endings of the intervals. | v:The values within the specified intervals.
RETURNS:Coefficients of the values within a specified intervals.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.inverseLerp(Unigine.vec4,Unigine.vec4,Unigine.vec4)
DESC:Returns the vector with four float values calculated according to the following formula: (v - v0) / (v1 - v0) clamped within 0.0f and 1.0f.
PARAMS:v0:Vector storing the values that specify the beginnings of the intervals. | v1:Vector storing the values that specify the endings of the intervals. | v:The values within the specified intervals.
RETURNS:Coefficients of the values within a specified intervals.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.inverseLerp(Unigine.dvec2,Unigine.dvec2,Unigine.dvec2)
DESC:Returns the vector with two double values calculated according to the following formula: (v - v0) / (v1 - v0) clamped within 0.0 and 1.0.
PARAMS:v0:Vector storing the values that specify the beginnings of the intervals. | v1:Vector storing the values that specify the endings of the intervals. | v:The values within the specified intervals.
RETURNS:Coefficients of the values within a specified intervals.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.inverseLerp(Unigine.dvec3,Unigine.dvec3,Unigine.dvec3)
DESC:Returns the vector with three double values calculated according to the following formula: (v - v0) / (v1 - v0) clamped within 0.0 and 1.0.
PARAMS:v0:Vector storing the values that specify the beginnings of the intervals. | v1:Vector storing the values that specify the endings of the intervals. | v:The values within the specified intervals.
RETURNS:Coefficients of the values within a specified intervals.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.inverseLerp(Unigine.dvec4,Unigine.dvec4,Unigine.dvec4)
DESC:Returns the vector with four double values calculated according to the following formula: (v - v0) / (v1 - v0) clamped within 0.0 and 1.0.
PARAMS:v0:Vector storing the values that specify the beginnings of the intervals. | v1:Vector storing the values that specify the endings of the intervals. | v:The values within the specified intervals.
RETURNS:Coefficients of the values within a specified intervals.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.contrastLerp(Unigine.vec4,Unigine.vec4,float,float,float)
DESC:Performs a smooth interpolation between two vectors (point_a and point_b) using a specified coefficient range to create a smooth transition effect.
PARAMS:point_a:Vector. | point_b:Vector. | coef_min_bound:The minimum value defining the range of the coefficient for the smoothstep function, creating a softened transition over the range. | coef_max_bound:The maximum value defining the range of the coefficient for the smoothstep function, creating a softened transition over the range. | coef:The coefficient value that determines the interpolation position between vectors.
RETURNS:.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.length2(Unigine.vec2)
DESC:Calculates the squared length of a given vector. This method is much faster than length() - the calculation is basically the same only without the slow Sqrt call. If you are using lengths simply to compare distances, then it is faster to compare squared lengths against the squares of distances as the comparison gives the same result.
PARAMS:v:Vector.
RETURNS:Squared length of the vector (X2 + Y2 + Z2).

PARAMS:v:Vector.
RETURNS:Squared length of the vector (X2 + Y2 + Z2).

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.normalize(Unigine.quat)
DESC:Normalizes a quaternion, makes its magnitude equal to 1. When normalized, a quaternion keeps the same oreintation but its magnitude is equal to 1.
PARAMS:v:A quaternion to be normalized.
RETURNS:Normalized quaternion.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.normalize(Unigine.vec2)
DESC:Normalizes a vector, makes its magnitude equal to 1. When normalized, a vector keeps the same direction but its length is equal to 1.
PARAMS:v:A two-component vec2 vector to be normalized.
RETURNS:Normalized vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.normalize(Unigine.vec3)
DESC:Normalizes a vector, makes its magnitude equal to 1. When normalized, a vector keeps the same direction but its length is equal to 1.
PARAMS:v:A three-component vec3 vector to be normalized.
RETURNS:Normalized vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.normalize(Unigine.vec4)
DESC:Normalizes a vector, makes its magnitude equal to 1. When normalized, a vector keeps the same direction but its length is equal to 1.
PARAMS:v:A four-component vec4 vector to be normalized.
RETURNS:Normalized vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.normalize(Unigine.dvec2)
DESC:Normalizes a vector, makes its magnitude equal to 1. When normalized, a vector keeps the same direction but its length is equal to 1.
PARAMS:v:A two-component dvec2 vector to be normalized.
RETURNS:Normalized vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.normalize(Unigine.dvec3)
DESC:Normalizes a vector, makes its magnitude equal to 1. When normalized, a vector keeps the same direction but its length is equal to 1.
PARAMS:v:A three-component dvec3 vector to be normalized.
RETURNS:Normalized vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.normalize(Unigine.dvec4)
DESC:Normalizes a vector, makes its magnitude equal to 1. When normalized, a vector keeps the same direction but its length is equal to 1.
PARAMS:v:A four-component dvec4 vector to be normalized.
RETURNS:Normalized vector.
-

DESC:Normalizes an input angle to the range (−180, 180).
PARAMS:angle:Angle value, in degrees.
RETURNS:Normalized angle value, in degrees.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.normalizeValid(Unigine.quat)
DESC:Normalizes a quaternion, makes its magnitude equal to 1. When normalized, a quaternion keeps the same oreintation but its magnitude is equal to 1. Check for the zero vector is performed: if the argument is a zero vector, then a zero vector is returned.
PARAMS:v:A quaternion to be normalized.
RETURNS:Normalized quaternion.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.normalizeValid(Unigine.vec2)
DESC:Normalizes a vector, makes its magnitude equal to 1. When normalized, a vector keeps the same direction but its length is equal to 1. Check for the zero vector is performed: if the argument is a zero vector, then a zero vector is returned.
PARAMS:v:A two-component vec2 vector to be normalized.
RETURNS:Normalized vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.normalizeValid(Unigine.vec3)
DESC:Normalizes a vector, makes its magnitude equal to 1. When normalized, a vector keeps the same direction but its length is equal to 1. Check for the zero vector is performed: if the argument is a zero vector, then a zero vector is returned.
PARAMS:v:A three-component vec3 vector to be normalized.
RETURNS:Normalized vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.normalizeValid(Unigine.vec4)
DESC:Normalizes a vector, makes its magnitude equal to 1. When normalized, a vector keeps the same direction but its length is equal to 1. Check for the zero vector is performed: if the argument is a zero vector, then a zero vector is returned.
PARAMS:v:A four-component vec4 vector to be normalized.
RETURNS:Normalized vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.normalizeValid(Unigine.dvec2)
DESC:Normalizes a vector, makes its magnitude equal to 1. When normalized, a vector keeps the same direction but its length is equal to 1. Check for the zero vector is performed: if the argument is a zero vector, then a zero vector is returned.
PARAMS:v:A two-component dvec2 vector to be normalized.
RETURNS:Normalized vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.normalizeValid(Unigine.dvec3)
DESC:Normalizes a vector, makes its magnitude equal to 1. When normalized, a vector keeps the same direction but its length is equal to 1. Check for the zero vector is performed: if the argument is a zero vector, then a zero vector is returned.
PARAMS:v:A three-component dvec3 vector to be normalized.
RETURNS:Normalized vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.normalizeValid(Unigine.dvec4)
DESC:Normalizes a vector, makes its magnitude equal to 1. When normalized, a vector keeps the same direction but its length is equal to 1. Check for the zero vector is performed: if the argument is a zero vector, then a zero vector is returned.
PARAMS:v:A four-component dvec4 vector to be normalized.
RETURNS:Normalized vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.normalize2(float)
DESC:Normalizes a 2-component vector, making it a unit vector (a vector with a length of 1) while preserving its direction.
PARAMS:v:Pointer to the vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.normalize3(float)
DESC:Normalizes a 3-component vector, making it a unit vector (a vector with a length of 1) while preserving its direction.
PARAMS:v:Pointer to the vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.normalize3(Unigine.vec4)
DESC:Normalizes a vector making its magnitude equal to 1. The vector is normalized as if it has only the first three components (the fourth one is ignored).
PARAMS:v:A four-component vec4 vector to be normalized.
RETURNS:Normalized vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.normalize3(Unigine.dvec4)
DESC:Normalizes a vector making its magnitude equal to 1. The vector is normalized as if it has only the first three components (the fourth one is ignored).
PARAMS:v:A four-component dvec4 vector to be normalized.
RETURNS:Normalized vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.normalizeValid3(Unigine.vec4)
DESC:Normalizes a vector making its magnitude equal to 1. The vector is normalized as if it has only the first three components (the fourth one is ignored). Check for the zero vector is performed: if the argument is a zero vector, then a zero vector is returned.
PARAMS:v:A four-component vec4 vector to be normalized.
RETURNS:Normalized vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.normalizeValid3(Unigine.dvec4)
DESC:Normalizes a vector making its magnitude equal to 1. The vector is normalized as if it has only the first three components (the fourth one is ignored). Check for the zero vector is performed: if the argument is a zero vector, then a zero vector is returned.
PARAMS:v:A four-component dvec4 vector to be normalized.
RETURNS:Normalized vector.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.rotate3(Unigine.quat)

PARAMS:q:Quaternion.
RETURNS:Resulting rotation matrix.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.round(double)
DESC:Rounds an argument to the nearest integer value. In halfway cases, when an argument has a fractional part of exactly 0.5, the function rounds away from zero to the integer with larger magnitude. 3.5 -> 4 - 3.5 -> - 4
PARAMS:v:Argument.
RETURNS:Nearest integer value to the argument.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.round(float)
DESC:Rounds an argument to the nearest integer value. In halfway cases, when an argument has a fractional part of exactly 0.5, the function rounds away from zero to the integer with larger magnitude. 3.5 -> 4 - 3.5 -> - 4
PARAMS:v:Argument.
RETURNS:Nearest integer value to the argument.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.roundFast(float)
DESC:Rounds an argument to the nearest integer value by adding 0.5 to the argument and discarding the decimal part. This method works for positive numbers but has limitations for negative numbers because it doesn't handle rounding in the traditional way for negative values.
PARAMS:v:Argument.
RETURNS:Nearest integer value to the argument.
-

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.unsafeToMat2x2(float)
DESC:Performs an unsafe conversion of the specified pointer to a source array containing matrix data to the dedicated type used to store elements of a 2x2 matrix. Make sure that the number of elements and their positions in the pointed source array matches the target type, otherwise you may get wrong data or end up with a crash.
PARAMS:data:Pointer to the matrix data.
RETURNS:The value storing matrix float values.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.udiv(int,int)
DESC:Performs integer division with rounding up: it adds 1 to the result if there is a remainder from the division.
PARAMS:x:First argument. | y:Second argument.
RETURNS:The rounded up quotient of two arguments that satisfies the following condition: y * z >= x.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.vogelDisk(uint,uint,float)
DESC:Returns a generated set of points with X and Y coordinates in the [-1; 1] range that describe a circle with uniform distribution of samples inside. This method is suitable for getting uniform distribution of coordinates for a circle. For example you can use it is a loop to generate UV coordinates offset for making the uniform circular blur effect. You can use the current loop iteration index as the i argument and the maximum number of iterations — as count.
PARAMS:i:Index of the current point for the disk. | count:Number of points. | noise:Normalized noise.
RETURNS:Set of points with X and Y coordinates in the [-1; 1] range that describe a circle with uniform distribution of samples inside.
-

You can use the current loop iteration index as the i argument and the maximum number of iterations — as count.
PARAMS:i:Index of the current point for the disk. | count:Number of points.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.composeRotationXYZ(Unigine.vec3)
DESC:Composes a rotation matrix from the corresponding Euler angles. The Euler angles are specified in the axis rotation sequence - XYZ. It is an order of the rings in the three-axis gimbal set: X axis used as the outer ring (independent ring), while Z axis as the inner one (its rotation depends on other 2 rings). When we talk about axes in UNIGINE we assume that: X axis points to the right giving us a pitch angle. Y axis points forward giving us a roll angle. Z axis points up giving us a yaw (heading) angle. Players have a different coordinate system: X axis points to the right giving us a pitch angle. Y axis points up giving us a yaw (heading) angle. Z axis points backward giving us a -roll angle.
PARAMS:r:Vector, containing Euler angles, in degrees - (yaw, roll, pitch).
RETURNS:Composed rotation matrix.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.composeRotationXZY(Unigine.vec3)
DESC:Composes a rotation matrix from the corresponding Euler angles. The Euler angles are specified in the axis rotation sequence - XZY. It is an order of the rings in the three-axis gimbal set: X axis used as the outer ring (independent ring), while Y axis as the inner one (its rotation depends on other 2 rings). When we talk about axes in UNIGINE we assume that: X axis points to the right giving us a pitch angle. Y axis points forward giving us a roll angle. Z axis points up giving us a yaw (heading) angle. Players have a different coordinate system: X axis points to the right giving us a pitch angle. Y axis points up giving us a yaw (heading) angle. Z axis points backward giving us a -roll angle.
PARAMS:r:Vector, containing Euler angles, in degrees - (yaw, roll, pitch).
RETURNS:Composed rotation matrix.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.composeRotationYXZ(Unigine.vec3)
DESC:Composes a rotation matrix from the corresponding Euler angles. The Euler angles are specified in the axis rotation sequence - YXZ. It is an order of the rings in the three-axis gimbal set: Y axis used as the outer ring (independent ring), while Z axis as the inner one (its rotation depends on other 2 rings). When we talk about axes in UNIGINE we assume that: X axis points to the right giving us a pitch angle. Y axis points forward giving us a roll angle. Z axis points up giving us a yaw (heading) angle. Players have a different coordinate system: X axis points to the right giving us a pitch angle. Y axis points up giving us a yaw (heading) angle. Z axis points backward giving us a -roll angle.
PARAMS:r:Vector, containing Euler angles, in degrees - (yaw, roll, pitch).
RETURNS:Composed rotation matrix.
-

(X, Y, Z) - represent translation, W = (scale.X + scale.Y + scale.z) / 3. | rot:Output quaternion, to which the rotation component of the transformation will pe put.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.frustum(float,float,float,float,float,float)
DESC:Returns perspective projection matrix: Coordinates of top, left, right, bottom are set relatively to center point of the znear plane. There are two different points (A and B) on the picture above. Since the top, left, right, bottom are coordinates relatively to the center point of the znear plane, coordinates of the A point should be A(left, bottom, znear). Coordinates of the B point are B(k * left, k * bottom, zfar), where k = zfar/znear.
PARAMS:left:Left coordinate of the near clipping plane relatively to the center. | right:Right coordinate of the near clipping plane relatively to the center. | bottom:Bottom coordinate of the near clipping plane relatively to the center. | top:Top coordinate of the near clipping plane relatively to the center. | znear:Distance to the near depth clipping plane. | zfar:Distance to the farther depth clipping plane.
RETURNS:Perspective projection matrix.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.inverse4(Unigine.mat4)

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.lookAt(Unigine.vec3,Unigine.vec3,Unigine.vec3,int)
DESC:Returns a view matrix for the given eye point, target point, up and forward direction vectors. The forward direction vector is oriented along the specified axis (negative Z, by default). This function is used to create a view matrix that positions and orients a camera or object in 3D space to "look at" a given target point.
PARAMS:position:Coordinates of the eye point position. | target:Coordinates of the target point position. | up:Direction of the up vector. | axis:Axis along which the forward direction vector is oriented (which axis should face the target). One of the AXIS_* values (by default it's AXIS_NZ).
RETURNS:The viewing matrix.

PARAMS:position:Coordinates of the eye point position. | target:Coordinates of the target point position. | up:Direction of the up vector. | axis:Axis along which the forward direction vector is oriented (which axis should face the target). One of the AXIS_* values (by default it's AXIS_NZ).

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.setTo(Unigine.dvec3,Unigine.dvec3,Unigine.vec3,int)
DESC:Returns the a transformation matrix, which puts an object to the specified position and sets it orientation to the specified target point. The forward direction vector is oriented along the specified axis (negative Z, by default). This function is similar to the lookAt() function, but instead of creating a view matrix for a camera, it creates a model matrix for positioning and orienting an object. This can be used to position objects in world space, aligning them to look at a target while maintaining a specific orientation relative to the "up" direction.
PARAMS:position:Coordinates of the eye point position. | target:Coordinates of the target point position. | up:Direction of the up vector. | axis:Axis along which the forward direction vector is oriented (which axis should face the target). One of the AXIS_* values (by default it's AXIS_NZ).
RETURNS:Transformation matrix.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.setTo(Unigine.vec3,Unigine.vec3,Unigine.vec3,int)
DESC:Returns the a transformation matrix, which puts an object to the specified position and sets it orientation to the specified target point. The forward direction vector is oriented along the specified axis (negative Z, by default). This function is similar to the lookAt() function, but instead of creating a view matrix for a camera, it creates a model matrix for positioning and orienting an object. This can be used to position objects in world space, aligning them to look at a target while maintaining a specific orientation relative to the "up" direction.
PARAMS:position:Coordinates of the eye point position. | target:Coordinates of the target point position. | up:Direction of the up vector. | axis:Axis along which the forward direction vector is oriented (which axis should face the target). One of the AXIS_* values (by default it's AXIS_NZ).
RETURNS:Transformation matrix.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.symmetryProjection(Unigine.mat4)
DESC:Returns a symmetric projection matrix for the specified input projection matrix. Symmetric projection ensures that the view frustum is symmetric about the x and y axes, based on the original frustum dimensions. This could be useful in cases where asymmetry in the projection matrix might cause issues, such as distortion in the rendered scene or when performing specific visual effects (e.g., mirroring or aligning views). The result is a projection matrix that maintains the same depth-related behavior as the original one but ensures symmetry in the x and y directions.
PARAMS:projection:Input projection matrix.
RETURNS:Symmetric projection matrix.
-

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.findIntersection(Unigine.vec2,Unigine.vec2,Unigine.vec2,Unigine.vec2,int,int,Unigine.vec2,Unigine.vec2,Unigine.vec2)
DESC:Finds the point of intersection between the two lines specified by the pairs of points p1 - p2 and p3 - p4 and fills in the values of the last 5 arguments.
PARAMS:p1:Start point coordinates of the first line segment. | p2:End point coordinates of the first line segment. | p3:Start point coordinates of the second line segment. | p4:End point coordinates of the second line segment. | lines_intersect:1 if the lines to which the segments belong intersect; otherwise, 0. | segments_intersect:1 if the segments intersect; otherwise, 0. | intersection:Coordinates of the point of intersection between the two line segments. | close_p1:Coordinates of the first of the two closest points belonging to the first segment. | close_p2:Coordinates of the second of the two closest points belonging to the second segment.
-

RETURNS:1 if the segments intersect; otherwise, 0.
-

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.resizePolygon(Unigine.Vector{Unigine.vec2,int,Unigine.VectorAllocator},float,Unigine.Vector{Unigine.vec2,int,Unigine.VectorAllocator},int)
DESC:Returns a set of points representing a resized polygon. The polygon is modified by moving its edges inward or outward by a specified offset. This is commonly referred to as "inflating" or "deflating" a polygon, depending on whether the offset is positive (expansion) or negative (contraction). Supports concave polygons, CCW and CW orientations.
PARAMS:points:Vector containing all points of the polygon. | offset:The value to which each polygon point is moved outward (positive value) or inward (negative value). | result_points:Vector containing all points of the deflated/inflated polygon. | append_to_result:Flag indicating if resulting points should be appended to the points of initial polygon - 0 (the default value), or replace them - 1.
-

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Geometry.irayBoundBoxIntersection(Unigine.Math.dvec3,Unigine.Math.dvec3,Unigine.Math.dvec3,Unigine.Math.dvec3)

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.quat.log(Unigine.vec3,Unigine.quat)
DESC:Converts a quaternion into a rotation vector in 3D space by computing the quaternion's logarithm. It extracts the axis of rotation and scales it by the angle, storing the result in the argument vector ret.
PARAMS:ret:Value to store the result. | q:Quaternion.
RETURNS:Resulting vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.quat.log(Unigine.quat)

RETURNS:Resulting vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.quat.log(Unigine.quat,Unigine.vec3)
DESC:Converts a 3D rotation vector into a quaternion. If the length of the input vector is very small, the quaternion is close to an identity quaternion. Otherwise, the function computes the sine and cosine of the half angle and constructs the quaternion to represent the rotation described by the vector.
PARAMS:ret:Value to store the result. | v:Rotation vector.
RETURNS:Resulting quaternion.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Math.quat.log(Unigine.vec3)
DESC:Converts a 3D rotation vector into a quaternion. If the length of the input vector is very small, the quaternion is close to an identity quaternion. Otherwise, the function computes the sine and cosine of the half angle and constructs the quaternion to represent the rotation described by the vector.
PARAMS:q:Rotation vector.
RETURNS:Resulting quaternion.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.optimizeIndices(int,int)
DESC:Optimizes indices of the given mesh surface. As polygons are added to a surface, vertices of the adjacent polygons are duplicated (you can get the number of such the vertices by using the getNumTVertex()), because normals, texture coordinates and tangents of such the vertices differ depending on the polygons, to which this vertices belongs. The optimizeIndices() function serves to decrease the number of such vertices and create indices for them that will be stored in the corresponding normals, tangents and texture coordinates.
PARAMS:flags:One of the flags used for indices' optimization: MESH_BACK_TO_FRONT or MESH_VERTEX_CACHE. | surface:Mesh surface number.
RETURNS:1 if the indices are optimized successfully; otherwise, 0.
-

PARAMS:surface:Mesh surface number.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.setSpatialTreeTriangles(int)
DESC:Sets the number of triangles stored in each leaf node of the mesh's spatial tree. Lower values (default is 4) improve the precision of intersection and collision detections, but increase spatial tree generation time and memory usage. Higher values reduce generation cost and memory consumption at the expense of intersection and collision detections accuracy. Useful for high-poly meshes or frequently updated procedural geometry.
PARAMS:triangles:Number of triangles per spatial tree leaf node.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.getSpatialTreeTriangles const
DESC:Returns the number of triangles currently configured per spatial tree leaf node.
RETURNS:Triangle count per leaf node (default is 4).

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.hasEdges(int) const
DESC:Checks whether edge data has been generated for the specified surface. If -1 is passed, checks all surfaces.
PARAMS:surface:Index of the surface to check. If -1 is passed, all surfaces will be updated.
RETURNS:Returns true if edge data exists, or if the surface has no geometry (empty edges are assumed).Returns false if the surface has geometry, but no edge data has been generated.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.createEdges(int)
DESC:Generates edge data for the specified surface. If -1 is passed, edge data will be generated for all surfaces.
PARAMS:surface:Index of the surface to check. Index of the surface. If -1 is passed, the operation will be performed for all surfaces.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.clearCollisionData(int,int)
DESC:Clears the specified types of collision data for the given surface. The behavior is controlled by the flags parameter, which determines which data types to clear. If -1 is passed for the surface parameter, the operation will be performed for all surfaces.
PARAMS:surface:Index of the surface. If -1 is passed, collision data will be cleared for all surfaces. | flags:Bitmask that specifies which types of collision data to clear.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.createCollisionData(int,int)
DESC:Generates specified types of collision data for the given surface. The behavior is controlled by the flags parameter, which determines which data types are created. This method must be called after any modification of mesh geometry. Otherwise, intersections and collisions may produce incorrect results due to outdated internal mesh structures.
PARAMS:surface:Index of the surface to process. If -1 is passed, all surfaces will be updated. | flags:Bitmask that specifies which types of collision data to generate.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.hasCollisionData(int,int) const
DESC:Checks whether the specified types of collision data exist for the given surface. The check is controlled by the flags parameter, which indicates which data types to validate. If -1 is passed for surface parameter, checks all surfaces in the mesh. This method does not validate geometry content. Instead, if a surface lacks valid geometry (e.g., no indices, empty targets), it is treated as not requiring collision data, and the function returns true.
PARAMS:surface:Index of the surface to check. If -1 is passed, all surfaces in the mesh are checked. | flags:Bitmask that specifies which types of collision data to check.
RETURNS:Returns true if collision data exists, or surface has no valid geometry, false otherwise.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.clearSurface(int,int)
DESC:Clears vertex data for the specified surface and target. If -1 is passed, all surfaces and targets will be cleared.
PARAMS:surface:Index of the surface to clear. If -1 is passed, all surfaces will be cleared. | target:Index of the target to clear. If -1 is passed, all targets within the surface will be cleared.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.getRandomPoint(Unigine.Math.vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3,int) const
DESC:Generates a random point on the specified surface, along with its normal. The velocity is always set to zero.
PARAMS:ret_point:Generated point on the surface. | ret_normal:Interpolated normal at the point. | ret_velocity:Always zero. | surface:Index of the surface to generate the random point on.
RETURNS:Returns true if a valid surface was found and the point was generated, false otherwise.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.getSurfaceCollision(Unigine.Math.BoundBox,Unigine.Vector{int,int,Unigine.VectorAllocator}) const
DESC:Checks for surface-level collisions between the mesh and a bounding box.
PARAMS:bb:Bounding box to check for collisions. | surfaces:Output vector to recieve indices of intersecting surfaces.
RETURNS:Returns true if at least one surface collided with the given bounding box, false otherwise.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.getSurfaceCollision(Unigine.Math.BoundFrustum,Unigine.Vector{int,int,Unigine.VectorAllocator}) const
DESC:Checks for surface-level collisions between the mesh and a bounding frustum.
PARAMS:bf:Bounding frustum to check for collisions. | surfaces:Output vector to recieve indices of intersecting surfaces.
RETURNS:Returns true if at least one surface collided with the given bounding frustum, false otherwise.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.getSurfaceCollision(Unigine.Math.vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3,Unigine.Vector{int,int,Unigine.VectorAllocator}) const
DESC:Checks for surface-level collisions between the mesh and a line segment.
PARAMS:p0:Start point of the line segment. | p1:End point of the line segment. | surfaces:Output vector to recieve indices of intersecting surfaces.
RETURNS:Returns true if at least one surface collided with the given line segment, false otherwise.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.getTriangleCollision(Unigine.Math.BoundBox,Unigine.Vector{int,int,Unigine.VectorAllocator},int) const
DESC:Checks for collisions between the specified bounding box and triangles on the given surface. If any triangles intersect the box, their indices are added to the OUT_triangles array.
PARAMS:bb:Bounding box to check for collisions. | triangles:Output vector to store the indices of intersected triangles. | surface:Index of the surface to check.
RETURNS:true if any triangle was intersected, otherwise false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.getTriangleCollision(Unigine.Math.BoundFrustum,Unigine.Vector{int,int,Unigine.VectorAllocator},int) const
DESC:Checks for collisions between the specified frustum and triangles on the given surface. If any triangles intersect the frustum, their indices are written to the OUT_triangles array.
PARAMS:bf:Bounding frustum to check for collisions. | triangles:Output vector to store the indices of intersected triangles. | surface:Index of the surface to check.
RETURNS:true if any triangle was intersected, otherwise false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.getTriangleCollision(Unigine.Math.vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3,Unigine.Vector{int,int,Unigine.VectorAllocator},int) const
DESC:Checks for collisions between the line segment defined by p0 and p1, and the triangles on the specified surface. If any triangles intersect the line segment, their indices are added to OUT_triangles.
PARAMS:p0:Start point of the line segment. | p1:End point of the line segment. | triangles:Output vector to store the indices of intersected triangles. | surface:Index of the surface to check.
RETURNS:true if any triangle was intersected, otherwise false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.getIntersection(Unigine.Math.dvec3,Unigine.Math.dvec3,Unigine.Math.dvec3,Unigine.Math.vec3,int,int,int) const
DESC:Performs a ray-triangle intersection test against the specified surface and target. If an intersection occurs, the closest intersection point, its normal, and the triangle index are returned via the corresponding output arguments.
PARAMS:p0:Start point of the ray in world coordinates. | p1:End point of the ray in world coordinates. | ret_point:Pointer to store the intersection point. | ret_normal:Pointer to store the surface normal at the intersection point. | ret_index:Pointer to store the triangle index of the intersection. | surface:Index of the surface to test. | target:Index of the target within the surface.
RETURNS:Returns true if the ray intersects any triangle within the mesh, false otherwise.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.clearSpatialTree(int)
DESC:Clears the spatial tree data for the specified surface. If -1 is passed, the spatial tree will be cleared for all surfaces.
PARAMS:surface:Index of the surface. If -1 is passed, spatial trees will be cleared for all surfaces in the mesh.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.clearEdges(int)
DESC:Clears edge data for the specified surface. If -1 is passed, edge data will be cleared for all surfaces in the mesh.
PARAMS:surface:Index of the surface. If -1 is passed, edge data will be cleared for all surfaces in the mesh.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.getSurfaceCollision(CollisionFilter,CollisionResult)
DESC:Performs a spatial query over all surfaces in the mesh, applying user-defined bounding box filter and invoking a callback for each matching surface index. This can be useful if you want to implement your own logic for collision detection based on bounding boxes.
PARAMS:filter:A function pointer or lambda with the following signature: bool filter(const Math::BoundBox& bb). The function should return true if the bounding box should be considered for collision; otherwise false. | surface_index_result:A function pointer or lambda with the following signature: void surface_index_result(int index). The function is invoked for each surface index whose bounding box passes the filter.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Mesh.getTriangleCollision(CollisionFilter,CollisionResult,int)
DESC:Performs a spatial query on a specific surface to detect colliding triangles. For each triangle whose bounding volume passes the given filter, a callback function is invoked with its index. If the surface has a spatial tree, the search is faster due to optimized traversal.
PARAMS:filter:A function pointer or lambda with the following signature: bool filter(const Math::BoundBox& bb). The function should return true if the bounding box should be considered for collision; otherwise false. | triangle_index_result:A function pointer or lambda with the following signature: void triangle_index_result(int index). The function is invoked for each triangle index whose bounding box passes the filter. | surface:The index of the surface to query.

DESC:Flag, which is used for mesh indices optimization. If this flag is set, polygons will be rendered in back-to-front order (from the exterior polygons to the central polygons of the mesh).

ENTRY:F:Unigine.Mesh.VERTEX_CACHE_LEGACY
DESC:Vertex cache optimization flag (legacy). Since v.2.20 the mesh indices optimization behavior has changed - use this flag for cases that require the previous behavior (for example, for lightmaps).

ENTRY:F:Unigine.Mesh.BACK_TO_FRONT_LEGACY
DESC:Flag used for rendering polygons in back-to-front order (legacy). Since v.2.20 the mesh indices optimization behavior has changed - use this flag for cases that require the previous behavior (for example, for lightmaps).

ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.create(int)
DESC:Creates a new dynamic mesh instance in accordance with the specified flags. The USAGE_IMMUTABLE_VERTEX flag cannot be used together with USAGE_DYNAMIC_VERTEX flag. The USAGE_IMMUTABLE_INDICES flag cannot be used together with USAGE_DYNAMIC_INDICES flag. USAGE_MISC_SHARED can be used only together with USAGE_IMMUTABLE_ALL.
PARAMS:flags:Creation flags. A combination of USAGE_IMMUTABLE_*, USAGE_DYNAMIC_* and USAGE_FLUSH_* flags.

Each attribute consists of:An offset of the vertex in bytes, depends on the vertex type and size.Type of the vertex: one of the TYPE_* valuesSize of the vertex: can be 1,2,3,4 for float type; 2,4 for half type; 4 for UChar typeWhen it goes to shader, 0 -attribute always comes with the size of 4, no matter what size is specified in the method. ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.clearIndices
DESC:Removes all indices of the dynamic mesh.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.allocateIndices(int)
DESC:Allocates a given number of vertex indices in the index buffer. With this function, memory can be allocated once rather than in chunks, making the creation faster.
PARAMS:num:Number of indices for which memory is to be allocated.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.removeIndices(int,int)
DESC:Removes the specified number of indices starting from the specified one from the index buffer of the dynamic mesh.
PARAMS:num:Number of the first index to be removed. | size:Number of indices to be removed.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.setNumIndices(int)
DESC:Sets the total number of indices for the dynamic mesh.
PARAMS:num:New number of indices.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.getNumIndices const
DESC:Returns the total number of indices for the dynamic mesh.
RETURNS:Number of indices.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.addIndex(int)
DESC:Adds a new index to the index buffer of the dynamic mesh.
PARAMS:index:Index to be added.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.addIndexFast(int)
DESC:Adds a new index to the index buffer of the dynamic mesh.
PARAMS:index:Index to be added.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.addIndices(int,int)
DESC:Adds two new indices to the index buffer of the dynamic mesh at once. This method can be used to add indices for a line strips via a single function call.
PARAMS:i0:First index to be added. | i1:Second index to be added.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.addIndices(int,int,int)
DESC:Adds three new indices to the index buffer of the dynamic mesh at once. This method can be used to add indices for a triangle via a single function call.
PARAMS:i0:First index to be added. | i1:Second index to be added. | i2:Third index to be added.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.addIndices(int,int,int,int)
DESC:Adds four new indices to the index buffer of the dynamic mesh at once. This method can be used to add indices for a quad via a single function call.
PARAMS:i0:First index to be added. | i1:Second index to be added. | i2:Third index to be added. | i3:Fourth index to be added.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.addIndicesArray(int,int)
DESC:Adds a set of new elements to the index buffer of the dynamic mesh at once.
PARAMS:indices:Array of indices to be added. | indices_size:Number of indices to be added.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.setIndicesArray(int,int)
DESC:Replaces the current index buffer of the dynamic mesh with the specified array of indices.
PARAMS:indices:Array of indices to be set. | indices_size:Number of indices to be set.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.getIndicesArray
DESC:Returns the index buffer of the dynamic mesh.
RETURNS:Vector containing the index buffer of the dynamic mesh.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.addPoints(int)
DESC:Adds the specified number of points to the dynamic mesh.
PARAMS:num_points:Number of points to be added.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.addLineStrip(int)
DESC:Adds a line strip to the dynamic mesh. This method does not add vertices, rather it allocates indices, for which vertices should be then created with one of the addVertex*() methods. Indices will point to vertices starting from the current last vertex in the vertex buffer.
PARAMS:num_vertex:Number of vertices comprising the strip.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.addTriangles(int)
DESC:Adds the specified number of triangles to the dynamic mesh.
PARAMS:num_triangles:Number of triangles to be added.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.addTriangleFan(int)
DESC:Adds a triangle fan to the dynamic mesh. This method does not add vertices, rather it allocates indices, for which vertices should be then created with one of the addVertex*() methods. Indices will point to vertices starting from the current last vertex in the vertex buffer.
PARAMS:num_vertex:Number of vertices comprising the fan.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.addTriangleStrip(int)
DESC:Adds a triangle strip to the dynamic mesh. This method does not add vertices, rather it allocates indices, for which vertices should be then created with one of the addVertex*() methods. Indices will point to vertices starting from the current last vertex in the vertex buffer.
PARAMS:num_vertex:Number of vertices comprising the strip.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.addTriangleQuads(int)
DESC:Adds a given number of quadrilaterals to the dynamic mesh. This method does not add vertices, rather it allocates indices, for which vertices should be then created with one of the addVertex*() methods. Indices will point to vertices starting from the current last vertex in the vertex buffer.
PARAMS:num_quads:Number of quadrilaterals to be added.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.saveState(Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Stream}) const
DESC:Saves the current state of the dynamic mesh (vertices, indices, etc.) to the specified stream. Saving into the stream requires creating a blob to save into. To restore the saved state the restoreState() method is used:
PARAMS:stream:Stream to which the state of the dynamic mesh is to be saved.
RETURNS:true if the current state of the dynamic mesh is saved successfully; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.restoreState(Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Stream})
DESC:Restores a previously saved state of the dynamic mesh (vertices, indices, etc.) from the specified stream. Restoring from the stream requires creating a blob to save into and saving the state using the saveState() method:
PARAMS:stream:Stream from which the previously saved state of the dynamic mesh is to be loaded.
RETURNS:true if a previously saved state of the dynamic mesh is restored successfully; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.getExternalMemoryVertexBuffer const
DESC:Returns the pointer to the vertex buffer of the resource in video memory. If the USAGE_MISC_SHARED flag is not enabled for the resource, this method returns nullptr.
RETURNS:The pointer to the vertex buffer of the resource in video memory. If the USAGE_MISC_SHARED flag is not enabled for the resource, this method returns nullptr.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.MeshDynamic.getExternalMemoryIndexBuffer const
DESC:Returns the pointer to the index buffer of the resource in video memory. If the USAGE_MISC_SHARED flag is not enabled for the resource, this method returns nullptr.
RETURNS:The pointer to the index buffer of the resource in video memory. If the USAGE_MISC_SHARED flag is not enabled for the resource, this method returns nullptr.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Node.setRotation(Unigine.Math.quat,bool)
DESC:Sets the node rotation.
PARAMS:rot:Quaternion representing node rotation in the local space. | identity:Flag indicating if node's scale is to be ignored or taken into account:false - node's scale is taken into account. In this case additional calculations are performed to extract current node's scale and apply it when building the final transformation matrix. These additional operations reduce performance and may lead to error accumulation.true - node's scale is ignored (assumed to be equal to 1 along all axes). Thus, the number of calculations performed for each rotation is reduced and error accumulation is minimal. | identity:It is recommended to set this flag for all non-scaled nodes to improve performance and accuracy.Scaling of nodes should be avoided whenever possible, as it requires addidional calculations and may lead to error accumulation.

In this case additional calculations are performed to extract current node's scale and apply it when building the final transformation matrix. These additional operations reduce performance and may lead to error accumulation.true - node's scale is ignored (assumed to be equal to 1 along all axes). Thus, the number of calculations performed for each rotation is reduced and error accumulation is minimal. | identity:It is recommended to set this flag for all non-scaled nodes to improve performance and accuracy.Scaling of nodes should be avoided whenever possible, as it requires addidional calculations and may lead to error accumulation.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Node.setDirection(Unigine.Math.vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3,MathLib::AXIS)
DESC:Updates the direction vector of the node and reorients this node: the specified axis of the node becomes oriented along the specified vector in local coordinates. For example, after running the code below, you will get the X axis of the node pointed along the Y axis in local coordinates.
PARAMS:dir:New direction vector in local coordinates. The direction vector always has unit length. | up:New up vector in local coordinates. If you skip this argument, the Z axis (in local coordinates) will be used. Note that the specified up vector is a hint vector only: the node's up vector points in the direction hinted by the specified up vector. The node's up vector matches the specified up vector (up) only if it is perpendicular to the specified direction vector (dir). | axis:Axis along which the direction vector should be pointed. The default is the negative Z axis.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Node.getDirection(MathLib::AXIS) const
DESC:Returns the normalized direction vector pointing along the given node axis in local coordinates (i.e. relative to the node's parent). By default, the direction vector pointing along the negative Z axis of the node (in local coordinates) is returned. The direction vector always has a unit length.
PARAMS:axis:Axis along which the direction vector points. The default is the negative Z axis.
RETURNS:Direction vector in local coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Node.setWorldDirection(Unigine.Math.vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3,MathLib::AXIS)
DESC:Updates the direction vector of the node and reorients this node: the specified axis of the node becomes oriented along the specified vector in world coordinates. For example, after running the code below, you will get the X axis of the node pointed along the Y axis in world coordinates:
PARAMS:dir:New direction vector in world coordinates. The direction vector always has unit length. | up:New up vector in world coordinates. If you skip this argument, the Z axis (in local coordinates) will be used. Note that the specified up vector is a hint vector only: the node's up vector points in the direction hinted by the specified up vector. The node's up vector matches the specified up vector (up) only if it is perpendicular to the specified direction vector (dir). | axis:Axis along which the direction vector should be pointed. The default is the negative Z axis.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Node.getWorldDirection(MathLib::AXIS) const
DESC:Returns the normalized direction vector pointing along the given node axis in world coordinates. By default, the direction vector pointing along the negative Z axis of the node is returned. The direction vector always has a unit length.
PARAMS:axis:Axis along which the direction vector points. The default is the negative Z axis.
RETURNS:Direction vector in world coordinates.
-

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Node.getLifetimeSelf const
DESC:Returns the lifetime management type set for the node itself. Lifetime of each node in the hierarchy is defined by it's root (either parent or possessor). Setting lifetime management type for a child node different from the one set for the root has no effect.
RETURNS:Lifetime management type for the node (see the LIFETIME enum).
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Node.getHierarchyBoundBox(bool) const
DESC:Returns a bounding box with local coordinates that takes children into account, but doesn't participate in physics calculations. Exclusion of objects from the spatial tree significantly reduces the size of the tree and improves performance due to saving time on bounding box recalculation when transforming nodes.
PARAMS:only_enabled_nodes:Set true to obtain the result taking into account only the nodes in the hierarchy that are enabled, or false - to take into account all nodes in the hierarchy regardless of theirenabled state.
RETURNS:The bounding box with world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Node.getHierarchyBoundSphere(bool) const
DESC:Returns a bounding sphere with local coordinates that takes children into account, but doesn't participate in physics calculations. Exclusion of objects from the spatial tree significantly reduces the size of the tree and improves performance due to saving time on bounding sphere recalculation when transforming nodes.
PARAMS:only_enabled_nodes:Set true to obtain the result taking into account only the nodes in the hierarchy that are enabled, or false - to take into account all nodes in the hierarchy regardless of theirenabled state.
RETURNS:The bounding sphere with world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Node.getHierarchyWorldBoundBox(bool) const
DESC:Returns a bounding box with world coordinates that takes children into account, but doesn't participate in physics calculations. Exclusion of objects from the spatial tree significantly reduces the size of the tree and improves performance due to saving time on bounding box recalculation when transforming nodes.
PARAMS:only_enabled_nodes:Set true to obtain the result taking into account only the nodes in the hierarchy that are enabled, or false - to take into account all nodes in the hierarchy regardless of theirenabled state.
RETURNS:The bounding box with world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Node.getHierarchyWorldBoundSphere(bool) const
DESC:Returns a bounding sphere with world coordinates that takes children into account, but doesn't participate in physics calculations. Exclusion of objects from the spatial tree significantly reduces the size of the tree and improves performance due to saving time on bounding sphere recalculation when transforming nodes.
PARAMS:only_enabled_nodes:Set true to obtain the result taking into account only the nodes in the hierarchy that are enabled, or false - to take into account all nodes in the hierarchy regardless of theirenabled state.
