ENTRY:M:Unigine.BonesRetargeting.save(char) const
DESC:Saves the current bones retargeting settings to a .bones_retargeting file according to the specified path. Such files can be uploaded to a created BonesRetargeting object, which may further be registered for an ObjectMeshSkinned and used via the method.
PARAMS:path:Path to a file to which bones retargeting settings are to be saved (.bones_retargeting extension).
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BonesRetargeting.load(char)
DESC:Loads bones retargeting settings from a .bones_retargeting file according to the specified path. Such files can be uploaded to a created BonesRetargeting object, which may further be registered for an ObjectMeshSkinned and used via the method.
PARAMS:path:Path to a file containing bones retargeting settings to be loaded (.bones_retargeting extension).
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BonesRetargeting.loadBones(char,char)
DESC:Loads the bone information from the source and the target meshes.
PARAMS:src_mesh_path:Path to the mesh file with the source bone settings. | dst_mesh_path:Path to the mesh file with the target bone settings.
RETURNS:true if the bone settings are loaded successfully, otherwise false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BonesRetargeting.loadBonesFromMeshes(Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Mesh},Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Mesh})
DESC:Loads the bone information from the source and the target meshes. Unlike the loadBones() method, this method uses loaded meshes, therefore it would be impossible to obtain mesh GUIDs via the getSrcMeshFileGUID() and getDstMeshFileGUID() methods.
PARAMS:src_mesh:The mesh with the source bone settings. | dst_mesh:The mesh with the target bone settings.
RETURNS:true if the bone settings are loaded successfully, otherwise false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BonesRetargeting.loadBonesFromObjects(Unigine.Ptr{ObjectMeshSkinned},Unigine.Ptr{ObjectMeshSkinned})
DESC:Loads the bone information from the source and the target MeshSkinned objects. MeshSkinned objects GUIDs will be possible to obtain unless the Procedural flag is enabled.
PARAMS:src_obj:The MeshSkinned object with the source bone settings. | dst_obj:The MeshSkinned object with the target bone settings.
RETURNS:true if the bone settings are loaded successfully, otherwise false.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.BonesRetargeting.MODE_ANIMATION
DESC:Bone position is taken from the source animation.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.BonesRetargeting.MODE_BIND
DESC:Bone position is taken from the bind-pose of the target skeleton.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.BonesRetargeting.MODE_PROPORTION
DESC:Bone position is taken from the source animation and multiplied by the proportion between the source and the target bones.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.ObjectParticles

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.setClearOnEnable(bool)
DESC:Enables or disables re-initialization of the particle system each time it is enabled. When this option is disabled, turning on the particle system will restore the state it had before it was turned off.

-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.isClearOnEnable const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if particle system is to be re-initialized each time it is enabled.
RETURNS:true if particle system is to be re-initialized each time it is enabled; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.setCollisionEnabled(bool)
DESC:Enables or disables collision detection for spheres that approximate each particle. This method is slower than intersection detection, but more precise.
PARAMS:enabled:true to enable sphere-based collision detection for particles, false to disable it.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.isCollisionEnabled const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if collision detection for spheres that approximate each particle. This method is slower than sphere center-based intersection detection, but more precise.
RETURNS:true if the sphere-based collision detection for particles is enabled; otherwise, false.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.setCollisionMask(int)
DESC:Sets a new Collision Mask to be used for particles. Particles will collide with an object, if they both have matching masks.
PARAMS:mask:New Collision Mask to be used for particles.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getCollisionMask const
DESC:Returns the current Collision Mask to be used for particles. Particles will collide with an object, if they both have matching masks.
RETURNS:Collision Mask currently used for particles.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.setPhysicsIntersectionEnabled(bool)
DESC:Enables or disables detecting collision by the center of the sphere that approximates the particles. This method is faster than collision detection, but less precise. Physics intersections are detected only for matching bit masks.
PARAMS:enabled:true to detect intersections, false not to detect.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.isPhysicsIntersectionEnabled const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if collisions are to be detected by the center of the sphere that approximates the particles. This method is faster than sphere-based collision detection, but less precise. Physics intersections are detected only for matching bit masks.
RETURNS:true if the sphere center-based intersection detection is enabled; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.setPhysicsIntersectionMask(int)
DESC:Sets a new Physics Intersection Mask to be used for particles. Physics intersections are detected only for matching bit masks.
PARAMS:mask:New Physics Intersection Mask to be used for particles.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getPhysicsIntersectionMask const
DESC:Returns the current Physics Intersection Mask for particles. Physics intersections are detected only for matching bit masks.
RETURNS:Current Physics Intersection Mask used for particles.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getContactNormal(int) const
DESC:Returns the point of the particles collision with other objects.
PARAMS:num:Collision point number.
RETURNS:Collision point coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getContactObject(int) const
DESC:Returns the object that collided with particles collided in a given collision point.
PARAMS:num:The collision point number.
RETURNS:The object participated in collision.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getContactPoint(int) const
DESC:Returns the normal vector for the collision point of the particles with other objects.
PARAMS:num:The collision point number.
RETURNS:Normal vector coordinates.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getContactVelocity(int) const
DESC:Returns the velocity in the collision point of the particles with other objects.

RETURNS:Velocity values for each of space dimensions.

DESC:Sets a value indicating if particles should disappear upon collision or intersection.
PARAMS:culling:1 to make particles disappear; 0 to continue rendering of particles after collision/intersection.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getCulling const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if particles would disappear upon collision or intersection.
RETURNS:1 if particles would disappear; otherwise, 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.setDelay(float,float)
DESC:Sets delay of particle system initialization relative to the parent particle one.
PARAMS:mean:A mean value in seconds. If a negative value is provided, 0 will be used instead. | spread:A spread value in seconds.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getDelayMean const
DESC:Returns the mean value of particles initialization delay relative to the parent particle system.
RETURNS:The mean value in seconds.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getDelaySpread const
DESC:Returns the spread value of particles initialization delay relative to the parent particle system.
RETURNS:The spread value in seconds.
-

-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getDepthSort const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if depth sorting of particles is enabled. Depth sorting is required, if particles use alpha blending.
RETURNS:true if the depth sorting is enabled; otherwise, false.

DESC:Sets a duration of each particle emission in seconds.

-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getDurationMean const
DESC:Returns the current mean value of particle emission intervals.
RETURNS:The mean value in seconds.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getDurationSpread const
DESC:Returns the current spread value of particle emission intervals.
RETURNS:The spread value in seconds.
-

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.isEmitterBased const

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.isEmitterContinuous const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if additional spawn points are generated when the emitter is moved, which provides a continuous flow of particles.
RETURNS:true if particles are created in the continuous flow; otherwise, false.

DESC:Enables or disables particle emission.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.isEmitterEnabled const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if particle emission is enabled.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.isEmitterShift const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if the emitter spawns particles only when it is moving. The further it has moved, if compared to its position in the previous frame, the more particles will be spawned. If the emitter is not moving, there are no particles at all.
RETURNS:true if the shift-based spawning is enabled; false if it is not.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.setEmitterSize(Unigine.Math.vec3)
DESC:Sets a size of the emitter.
PARAMS:size:A new emitter size. If negative values are provided, 0 will be used instead of them. Depending on the type of the emitter, this value is interpreted as follows:EMITTER_POINT, EMITTER_SPARK, EMITTER_RANDOM: all vector components are ignored.EMITTER_SPHERE: the first vector component is the radius of the sphere.EMITTER_CYLINDER: the first vector component is the radius of the cylinder, the second vector component is the height of the cylinder.EMITTER_BOX: all vector components are interpreted as box dimensions (x, y, z).
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getEmitterSize const
DESC:Returns the current emitter size.
RETURNS:The current size of the emitter. Depending on the type of the emitter, this value is interpreted as follows:EMITTER_POINT, EMITTER_SPARK, EMITTER_RANDOM: all vector components are ignored.EMITTER_SPHERE: the first vector component is the radius of the sphere.EMITTER_CYLINDER: the first vector component is the radius of the cylinder, the second vector component is the height of the cylinder.EMITTER_BOX: all vector components are interpreted as box dimensions (x, y, z).
-

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getEmitterSync const

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getEmitterType const

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getLifeMean const

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getLifeSpread const

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getParticleRadius(int) const

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getParticlesType const

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getParticleVelocity(int) const

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getPeriodMean const
DESC:Returns the current mean value of emitter inactivity intervals.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getPeriodSpread const

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.setProceduralParenting(int)
DESC:Sets the type of relationship between the particle system and a decal / field node that uses the procedural texture. Procedural rendering must be enabled.
PARAMS:parenting:Relationship type to be used for rendering the particle system to a procedural texture:0 - a decal/field node that uses the procedural texture is a child of the particle system.1 - a decal/field node that uses the procedural texture is a parent of the particle system.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getProceduralParenting const
DESC:Returns the current type of relationship between the particle system and a decal / field node that uses the procedural texture. Procedural rendering must be enabled.
RETURNS:Relationship type to be used for rendering the particle system to a procedural texture:0 - a decal/field node that uses the procedural texture is a child of the particle system.1 - a decal/field node that uses the procedural texture is a parent of the particle system.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.setProceduralPositioning(int)
DESC:Sets positioning mode to be used for child nodes using the procedural texture to which the particle system is rendered. Positioning mode can be set only when the particle system is a parent of a decal/field node that uses the procedural texture (parenting mode is set to 0) Procedural rendering must be enabled.
PARAMS:positioning:Mode of the procedural positioning. Can be one of the following:PROCEDURAL_POSITIONING_MANUAL = 0 - position of a child decal/field node, that uses the procedural texture, can be changed manually.PROCEDURAL_POSITIONING_AUTO = 1 - position of a child decal/field node, that uses the procedural texture, is automatically defined by the position of particle system and cannot be changed manually.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getProceduralPositioning const
DESC:Returns the value indicating the procedural position mode. Procedural rendering must be enabled.
RETURNS:Mode of the procedural positioning. Can be one of the following:PROCEDURAL_POSITIONING_MANUAL = 0PROCEDURAL_POSITIONING_AUTO = 1
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.setProceduralTextureResolution(Unigine.Math.vec3)
DESC:Sets the resolution of the procedural texture. Procedural rendering must be enabled.
PARAMS:res:Resolution of the texture.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getProceduralTextureResolution const
DESC:Returns the resolution of the procedural texture. Procedural rendering must be enabled.
RETURNS:Resolution of the texture.
-

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.setSpawnScale(float)

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.setScreenSizeMode(ObjectParticles::SCREEN_SIZE_MODE)
DESC:Sets a new screen size mode for particles. This mode defines whether the maximum and minimum sizes of emitted particles should be limited relative to screen size or not (e.g., to avoid cases when snowflakes or raindrops obscure the view if they are too close to the camera or when they become invisible as the distance to the camera increases). Three modes are available: NONE - minimum and maximum sizes of particles on the screen are not limited. WIDTH - minimum and maximum sizes of particles on the screen are limited relative to screen width. HEIGHT - minimum and maximum sizes of particles on the screen are limited relative to screen height.
PARAMS:mode:New screen size mode to be set for particles. One of the SCREEN_SIZE_MODE* values.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getScreenSizeMode const
DESC:Returns the current screen size mode for particles. This mode defines whether the maximum and minimum sizes of emitted particles should be limited relative to screen size or not (e.g., to avoid cases when snowflakes or raindrops obscure the view if they are too close to the camera or when they become invisible as the distance to the camera increases). Three modes are available: NONE - minimum and maximum sizes of particles on the screen are not limited. WIDTH - minimum and maximum sizes of particles on the screen are limited relative to screen width. HEIGHT - minimum and maximum sizes of particles on the screen are limited relative to screen height.
RETURNS:Current screen size mode for particles. One of the SCREEN_SIZE_MODE* values.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.setScreenMinSize(float)
DESC:Sets a new minimum screen size for particles (minimum fraction of the screen a single particle can occupy).
PARAMS:size:New minimum screen size to be set for particles. Minimum fraction of the screen a single particle can occupy:The minimum value of 0 means the particle has a zero size and therefore is invisible on the screen (occupies no space at all).The maximum value of 1 means the particle occupies the whole screen.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getScreenMinSize const
DESC:Returns the current minimum screen size for particles (minimum fraction of the screen a single particle can occupy). Any particle shall occupy at least the specified fraction of the screen.
RETURNS:Current minimum screen size for particles. Minimum fraction of the screen a single particle can occupy:The minimum value of 0 means the particle has a zero size and therefore is invisible on the screen (occupies no space at all).The maximum value of 1 means the particle occupies the whole screen.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.setScreenMaxSize(float)
DESC:Sets a new maximum screen size for particles (maximum fraction of the screen a single particle can occupy). Any particle shall occupy no more than the specified fraction of the screen, no matter how close the camera approaches it.
PARAMS:size:New maximum screen size to be set for particles. Maximum fraction of the screen a single particle can occupy:The minimum value of 0 means the particle has a zero size and therefore is invisible on the screen (occupies no space at all).The maximum value of 1 means the particle occupies the whole screen.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getScreenMaxSize const
DESC:Returns the current maximum screen size for particles (maximum fraction of the screen a single particle can occupy). Any particle shall occupy no more than the specified fraction of the screen, no matter how close the camera approaches it.
RETURNS:Current maximum screen size for particles. Maximum fraction of the screen a single particle can occupy:The minimum value of 0 means the particle has a zero size and therefore is invisible on the screen (occupies no space at all).The maximum value of 1 means the particle occupies the whole screen.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.setParticlesFieldMask(int)
DESC:Sets a new Particles Field bit mask enabling you to control interactions with Particles Fields. A Particles Field will interact with particles generated by a Particles System if they both have matching Particles Field masks (one bit at least).
PARAMS:mask:New Particles Field bit mask to be set for the particle system. Integer, each bit of which is a mask.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectParticles.getParticlesFieldMask const
DESC:Returns the current Particles Field bit mask enabling you to control interactions with Particles Fields. A Particles Field will interact with particles generated by a Particles System if they both have matching Particles Field masks (one bit at least).
RETURNS:Current Particles Field bit mask of the particle system. Integer, each bit of which is a mask.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ObjectParticles.EMITTER_POINT
DESC:Point emitter. Particles are emitted from one single point.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ObjectParticles.EMITTER_SPHERE
DESC:Sphere emitter. Particles are emitted from a random point of the sphere.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ObjectParticles.EMITTER_CYLINDER
DESC:Cylinder emitter. Particles are emitted from a random point of the cylinder.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ObjectParticles.EMITTER_BOX
DESC:Box emitter. Particles are emitted from a random point of the box.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ObjectParticles.EMITTER_RANDOM
DESC:Arbitrary emitter. Particles are emitted from a random point of their parent node. With an emitter of this type you can create particles, which spawn particles themselves.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ObjectParticles.EMITTER_SPARK
DESC:Spark emitter. Particles are emitted from a single point and imitate sparks.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ObjectParticles.TYPE_BILLBOARD
DESC:Particles of this type are camera-oriented and rotating.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ObjectParticles.TYPE_FLAT
DESC:Particles of this type are perpendicular to the z-axis of their particle system.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ObjectParticles.TYPE_POINT
DESC:Particles of this type are similar to billboard particles, but do not rotate.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ObjectParticles.TYPE_LENGTH
DESC:Particles of this type are similar to billboard particles, but stretched along the direction of their motion and do not rotate.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ObjectParticles.TYPE_RANDOM
DESC:Particles of this type are arbitrary oriented ones.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ObjectParticles.TYPE_ROUTE
DESC:Particles of this type can be used to create tracks from moving objects (for example, foam after a ship). Each Route particle is flat (just like flat particles), but is oriented on the plane in the same way as the emitter when it spawned it.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ObjectParticles.TYPE_CHAIN
DESC:Particles of this type are camera-oriented and connected with each other at vertices forming continuous flow.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ObjectParticles.SYNC_MODE_NONE
DESC:In this mode, the particle system neither provides nor takes any synchronization data.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ObjectParticles.SYNC_MODE_MASTER
DESC:This mode enables storing of the particle system data used for synchronization by the slave system.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ObjectParticles.SYNC_MODE_SLAVE
DESC:This mode makes a particle system take the stored synchronization data from the master particle system.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ObjectParticles.SCREEN_SIZE_MODE_NONE
DESC:Minimum and maximum sizes of particles on the screen are not limited.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ObjectParticles.SCREEN_SIZE_MODE_WIDTH
DESC:Minimum and maximum sizes of particles on the screen are limited relative to screen width.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ObjectParticles.SCREEN_SIZE_MODE_HEIGHT
DESC:Minimum and maximum sizes of particles on the screen are limited relative to screen height.
-

ENTRY:F:Unigine.ParticleModifier.PARTICLE_MODIFIER_SCALAR
DESC:In this mode the modifier controls a single scalar value via a single curve.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ParticleModifier.PARTICLE_MODIFIER_VECTOR
DESC:In this mode the modifier controls a vector of up to 4 values via a set of curves.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ParticleModifier.MODE_CONSTANT
DESC:In this mode the specified value is fixed throughout the lifetime.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ParticleModifier.MODE_RANDOM_BETWEEN_TWO_CONSTANTS
DESC:In this mode two constants define the upper and lower limits for the value. The actual value changes randomly over time between these limits.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ParticleModifier.MODE_CURVE
DESC:In this mode the modifier controls each value via a single curve.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ParticleModifier.MODE_RANDOM_BETWEEN_TWO_CURVES
DESC:In this mode two curves define the upper and lower limits for the value at each point of the lifetime. The actual value changes randomly over time between these limits.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ParticleModifier.NUM_MODES
DESC:Number of particle modifier's modes.
-

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectTerrainGlobal.setForceIntersection(bool)
DESC:Enables or disables forced loading of necessary terrain tiles to ensure correct intersection detection. When enabled, this option may significantly reduce performance. Thus, it is recommended to enable it, perform intersection check, and disable it again. It is recommended to make two or more intersection requests to make sure you get the required result when necessary, as in some rare cases forced loading of tiles may not give you a 100% guarantee.
PARAMS:intersection:true to load necessary terrain tiles for intersection detection; otherwise, false. The default value is false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectTerrainGlobal.isForceIntersection const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if forced loading of terrain tiles for intersection detection is enabled. This option is used to enable force loading of terrain tiles to ensure correct intersection detection.
RETURNS:true if forced loading of terrain tiles for intersection detection is enabled; otherwise, false.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.TerrainGlobalDetail.getDisplacement

ENTRY:M:Unigine.TerrainGlobalDetail.setDisplacementOffset(float)
DESC:Sets the displacement offset. This parameter controls the direction of displacement (inward or outward).
PARAMS:offset:Displacement offset value within the [-1.0f; 1.0f] range.positive value - outward displacement.0 - points corresponding to height texture values less than 0.5 are displaced inwards, others are displaced outwards.negative value - inward displacement.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.TerrainGlobalDetail.getDisplacementOffset
DESC:Returns the displacement offset. This parameter controls the direction of displacement (inward or outward).
RETURNS:Displacement offset value within the [-1.0f; 1.0f] range.positive value - outward displacement.0 - points corresponding to height texture values less than 0.5 are displaced inwards, others ar edisplaced outwards.negative value - inward displacement.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.TerrainGlobalDetail.getMaskThreshold

-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.TerrainGlobalDetail.getMaskWidth

-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.TerrainGlobalDetail.setMaxFadeDistance(float)
DESC:Sets the maximum fade-out distance of the detail. Over this distance the detail smoothly becomes invisible due to alpha fading. It is counted starting from the maximum visibility distance.
PARAMS:distance:Maximum fade-out distance, in units. If a negative value is provided, 0 will be used instead. The default value is 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.TerrainGlobalDetail.getMaxFadeDistance
DESC:Returns the maximum fade-out distance of the detail. Over this distance the detail smoothly becomes invisible due to alpha fading. It is counted starting from the maximum visibility distance.
RETURNS:Maximum fade-out distance, in units.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.TerrainGlobalDetail.setMaxFadeHeight(float)
DESC:Sets the fade out height range for the detail mask. Over this height range above the maximum height value the detail mask will fade out until it is completely invisible. This parameter is used to modulate the detail mask by height.
PARAMS:height:Fade out height range value for the mask, in units. The default value is 0. Higher values provide smoother fade out.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.TerrainGlobalDetail.getMaxFadeHeight
DESC:Returns the fade out height range for the detail mask. Over this height range above the maximum height value the detail mask will fade out until it is completely invisible. This parameter is used to modulate the detail mask by height.
RETURNS:Fade out height range value for the mask, in units.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.TerrainGlobalDetail.setMaxVisibleDistance(float)
DESC:Sets the maximum visibility distance of the detail. It is the distance, starting from which the detail begins to fade out until it becomes completely invisible. This parameter can be used to improve performance and reduce the tiling effect when looking at the terrain from a large distance.
PARAMS:distance:Maximum visibility distance, in units. If a negative value is provided, 0 will be used instead. The default value is inf.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.TerrainGlobalDetail.getMaxVisibleDistance
DESC:Returns the maximum visibility distance of the detail. It is the distance, starting from which the detail begins to fade out until it becomes completely invisible.
RETURNS:Maximum visibility distance, in units.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.TerrainGlobalDetail.setMaxVisibleHeight(float)
DESC:Sets the maximum height value for the detail mask, starting from which the detail begins to fade out until it becomes completely invisible. This parameter is used to modulate the detail mask by height.
PARAMS:height:Maximum height value for the mask, in units. The default value is inf.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.TerrainGlobalDetail.getMaxVisibleHeight
DESC:Sets the maximum height value for the detail mask, starting from which the detail begins to fade out until it becomes completely invisible. This parameter is used to modulate the detail mask by height.
RETURNS:Maximum height value for the mask, in units.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.TerrainGlobalDetail.getMinVisibleDistance

ENTRY:M:Unigine.TerrainGlobalDetail.getMinVisibleHeight

DESC:Returns parameters of one of four simulated water waves.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterMesh.setWaveAngle(int,float)
DESC:Sets direction (angle of spreading) for a given wave: If 0 is specified, the wave spreads along the Y axis and is parallel to the X axis. If a positive value is specified, the wave direction is slanted counterclockwise relative to its initial spread. If a negative value is specified, the wave is rotated clockwise.
PARAMS:num:Wave number in range [0;3]. | angle:Angle, in degrees. Both positive and negative values are acceptable.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterMesh.getWaveAngle(int)

RETURNS:Angle, in degrees.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterMesh.setWaveHeight(int,float)
DESC:Sets the distance between the highest and the lowest peaks for the given wave. It sets the wave form along with the setWaveLength() function. The higher the value is, the higher the waves are.
PARAMS:num:Wave number in range [0;3]. | height:Height, in units.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterMesh.getWaveHeight(int)
DESC:Returns the distance between the highest and the lowest peaks for the given wave.
PARAMS:num:Wave number in range [0;3].
RETURNS:Height, in units.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterMesh.setWaveLength(int,float)
DESC:Sets the distance between successive crests for the given wave. The higher the length value is, the broader the waves are.
PARAMS:num:Wave number in range [0;3]. | length:Length, in units.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterMesh.getWaveLength(int)
DESC:Returns the distance between successive crests of the given wave.
PARAMS:num:Wave number in range [0;3].
RETURNS:Length, in units.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterMesh.setWaveSpeed(int,float)
DESC:Sets a speed for a given wave. The higher the value, the faster waves follow each other.
PARAMS:num:Wave number in range [0;3]. | speed:Speed, in units per second.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterMesh.getWaveSpeed(int)
DESC:Returns the speed of a given wave.
PARAMS:num:Wave number in range [0;3].
RETURNS:Speed, in units per second.
-

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.fetchHeight(Unigine.Math.Vec3) const
DESC:Returns a height offset of the specified point relative to the current water level calculated at this point. E.g. in case the specified point is (0, 0, -3) and the current water level calculated for this point is equal to 5, the function shall return 8. In case of higher Beaufort levels (resulting in significant wave steepness and height differences on the water surface), calculation results may differ from visual representation (e.g. calculated water level may be greater the actual value). To avoid it and increase precision, adjust calculation quality.
PARAMS:position:Point position coordinates.
RETURNS:Height offset of the specified point relative to the current water level calculated at this point, in meters.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.fetchNormal(Unigine.Math.Vec3) const
DESC:Returns a normal vector to the water surface at the specified point (to orient objects along the waves normals).In case of higher Beaufort levels (resulting in significant wave steepness and height differences on the water surface), calculation results may differ from visual representation (e.g. calculated water level may be greater the actual value). To avoid it and increase precision, adjust calculation quality.
PARAMS:position:Point position coordinates.
RETURNS:Normal vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.setFetchAmplitudeThreshold(float)
DESC:Sets the threshold for amplitude values that will not participate in height and normal calculations. The more you cut off, the less accurate the height value you get, but the faster are the calculations.
PARAMS:threshold:Amplitude threshold. The default value is 0.1f.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.getFetchAmplitudeThreshold const
DESC:Returns the current threshold for amplitude values that will not participate in height and normal calculations.
RETURNS:Amplitude threshold.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.setFetchSteepnessQuality(ObjectWaterGlobal::STEEPNESS_QUALITY)
DESC:Sets the wave steepness calculation quality used in height and normal calculations. Low quality is usually sufficient for calm water and large floating objects. If the waves are big, or you want to simulate small floating objects, you may need to increase the quality. Higher quality gives a more precise result but affects performance.
PARAMS:quality:Quality value.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.getFetchSteepnessQuality const
DESC:Returns the wave steepness calculation quality used in height and normal calculations.
RETURNS:Steepness quality. The default is STEEPNESS_QUALITY_LOW.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.getIntersectionAmplitudeThreshold const
DESC:Returns the current threshold of amplitude values that will not participate in intersection calculations.
RETURNS:Amplitude threshold.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.setIntersectionAmplitudeThreshold(float)
DESC:Sets the threshold for amplitude values that will not participate in intersection calculations. The default value is 0.1f.
PARAMS:threshold:Amplitude threshold.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.setIntersectionPrecision(float)
DESC:Sets an intersection precision which represents an error between the real value of the water intersection point and the calculated value. The default value is 0.25.
PARAMS:precision:Precision for intersection detection.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.getIntersectionPrecision const
DESC:Returns current intersection precision which represents an error between the real value of the water intersection point and the calculated value.
RETURNS:Precision for intersection detection.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.setIntersectionSteepnessQuality(ObjectWaterGlobal::STEEPNESS_QUALITY)
DESC:Sets the wave steepness calculation quality used in intersection calculations. Low quality is usually sufficient for calm water and large floating objects. If the waves are big, or you want to simulate small floating objects, you may need to increase the quality. Higher quality gives a more precise result but affects performance.
PARAMS:quality:Steepness quality. The default is STEEPNESS_QUALITY_LOW.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.getIntersectionSteepnessQuality const
DESC:Returns the wave steepness calculation quality used in intersection calculations. Low quality is usually sufficient for calm water and large floating objects. If the waves are big, or you want to simulate small floating objects, you may need to increase the quality. Higher quality gives a more precise result but affects performance.
RETURNS:Steepness quality.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.setReflectionOcclusion(float)
DESC:Sets the occlusion factor for environment reflections on parts of the water surface with negative normals. Using this parameter enables simulation of reflection of waves on the water surface removing too bright areas on waves close to the horizon.
PARAMS:occlusion:Occlusion value. Minimum value is 0 - no occlusion. By the higher values, occlusion is performed for reflections on parts of the water surface with negative normals that have a certain slope. The higher the value, the less intensive reflections are on the surface parts with negative normals.

PARAMS:distortion:true to enable caustics distortion, false to disable it.

-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.isFieldShorelineEnabled const
DESC:Checks if the assigned material on the Global Water object has enabled FieldShoreline interaction option.
RETURNS:true if the FieldShoreline interaction option is enabled, otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.setFieldShorelineHighPrecision(bool)
DESC:Enables/disables improved interpolation between the adjacent pixels of the shoreline texture to reduce stepping artifacts. This can be noticed when looking at the waterline separating overwater and underwater. This option should be used only when geometry and/or normal states are enabled.
PARAMS:precision:true to enable high precision, false to disable it.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.isFieldShorelineHighPrecision const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if the high precision of the shoreline is enabled. If enabled, this option improves interpolation between the adjacent pixels of the shoreline texture to reduce stepping artifacts.
RETURNS:true if high precision is enabled, otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.setFieldShorelineNormal(bool)
DESC:Enables/disables calculation of normals for geometry of shoreline waves. This option significantly reduces performance and can be used in cases, when really large waves are required. Enabling just the geometry state to simulate distortion of the water surface by a shoreline wave is enough in most cases.
PARAMS:normal:true to enable, false to disable.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.isFieldShorelineNormal const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if calculation of normals for geometry of shoreline waves is enabled.
RETURNS:true if enabled, otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.setFieldShorelineGeometry(bool)
DESC:Enables/disables rendering of wave geometry for shoreline waves. If disabled, the water surface remains flat. Disabling this option in cases where wave geometry is hardly noticeable (e.g. a flight simulator) gives a performance gain.
PARAMS:geometry:true to enable, false to disable.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.isFieldShorelineGeometry const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if rendering of wave geometry for shoreline waves is enabled.
RETURNS:true if enabled, otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.setFieldShorelineFoam(bool)
DESC:Enables/disables rendering of foam for shoreline zones.
PARAMS:foam:true to enable, false to disable.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.isFieldShorelineFoam const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if rendering of foam for shoreline zones is enabled.
RETURNS:true if enabled, otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ObjectWaterGlobal.setAuxiliary(bool)
DESC:Enables/disables the auxiliary rendering pass for the material. Can be used for custom post-effects, such as thermal vision, night vision, etc. Enabling the option activates the Auxiliary Color parameter.
PARAMS:auxiliary:true to enable, false to disable.
-

FILE:UniginePackageUng.xml
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PackageUng.#ctor(char,char)
DESC:Constructor. Initializes a PackageUng object with an optional password and a specified list for the expressions to be compressed. By default, the list includes formats that do not require Data Streaming.
PARAMS:password:Password used to protect the archive. If empty, no password protection is applied. | compress_extension_list:A space-separated list of file extensions that should be compressed when added to the package.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PackageUng.close
DESC:Closes the currently opened package and resets internal state of PackageUng object.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PackageUng.createPackage(char)
DESC:Creates a new UNG package file at the specified path.
PARAMS:path:Package path.
RETURNS:true if a package was created successfully; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PackageUng.isSupported
DESC:Returns a value indicating if UNG-packages are supported.
RETURNS:true if UNG packages are supported; otherwise, false.UNG-packages are not supported in evaluation version.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PackageUng.load(char)
DESC:Loads an existing package from the specified path.
PARAMS:path:The path to the package file.
RETURNS:true if a package was loaded successfully; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PackageUng.readFile(unsignedchar,size_t)
DESC:Reads the contents of the currently selected file and puts it into the data array. This operation is performed for a currently selected file. To select a file use selectFile().
PARAMS:data:Data array. | size:File size, in bytes.
RETURNS:true if a file was read successfully; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PackageUng.selectFile(char,size_t)
DESC:Selects a file with a given path as a current one and puts its size in the provided variable.
PARAMS:path:Relative path of the file within the package. | size:A reference variable to store the size of the selected file.
RETURNS:true if a file was selected successfully; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PackageUng.writeFile(char,unsignedchar,size_t)
DESC:Writes data to the package with a given path.
PARAMS:path:File path. | data:Data to be written. | size:Size of the data to be written, in bytes.
RETURNS:true if the data was successfully written to a file; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PackageUng.containsFile(char) const
DESC:Checks if the package contains the specified file.
PARAMS:path:File path.
RETURNS:true if the package contains the specified file; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PackageUng.findFile(char) const
DESC:Returns the file ID in the package by its path.
PARAMS:path:File path.
RETURNS:File ID. A number between 0 and the total number of files in the package, or -1, if the file doesn't exist.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PackageUng.getFileSize(int) const
DESC:Returns the size of the file at the specified index within the package.
PARAMS:num:Index of the file in the package.
RETURNS:Size of the file in bytes.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PackageUng.getFilePath(int)
DESC:Returns the path of the file at the specified index.
PARAMS:num:Index of the file in the package.
RETURNS:A string representing the path of the file.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PackageUng.getFileCompressedSize(int) const
DESC:Returns the compressed size of the file at the specified index. Compression is applied only to files with extensions included in the compression list specified in the constructor.
PARAMS:num:Index of the file in the package.
RETURNS:The size of the file in its compressed form, in bytes.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PackageUng.isFileCompressed(int) const
DESC:Checks whether the file at specified index is stored in compressed form within the package. Compression is applied only to files with extensions included in the compression list specified in the constructor.
PARAMS:num:Index of the file in the package.
RETURNS:true if the specified file is compressed; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PackageUng.getNumCompressExtensions const
DESC:Returns the number of file extensions currently included in the compression list. The compression list is specified when the PackageUng object is constructed.
RETURNS:Number of file extensions in the compression list.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PackageUng.getCompressExtension(int) const
DESC:Retrieves a file extension from the compression list by it's index. The compression list is specified when the PackageUng object is constructed.
PARAMS:num:Index of the extension in the compression list.
RETURNS:The file extension at the given index.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PackageUng.isCompressExtension(char) const
DESC:Checks whether the specified file extension is in the compression list. The compression list is specified when the PackageUng object is constructed.
PARAMS:ext:The file extension to check (without a leading dot).
RETURNS:true if the specified extension is in compression list; otherwise, false.

FILE:UnigineParticlesFields.xml
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ParticlesField.setInteractParticleMode(ParticlesField::INTERACT_PARTICLE_MODE)
DESC:Sets a new interaction mode for the Particles Field. Interaction can be triggered on a contact of the field either with particle's center position or with its bounding box.
PARAMS:mode:New interaction mode to be set. One of the INTERACT_PARTICLE_MODE* values.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ParticlesField.getInteractParticleMode const
DESC:Returns the current interaction mode for the Particles Field. Interaction can be triggered on a contact of the field either with particle's center position or with its bounding box.
RETURNS:Current interaction mode of the Particles Field. One of the INTERACT_PARTICLE_MODE* values.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ParticlesField.setParticlesFieldMask(int)
DESC:Sets a new Particles Field bit mask enabling you to control interactions with particles. The Particles Field will interact with a Particles System if they both have matching Particles Field masks (one bit at least).
PARAMS:mask:New mask to be set for the field. Integer, each bit of which is a mask.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ParticlesField.getParticlesFieldMask const
DESC:Returns the current Particles Field bit mask enabling you to control interactions with particles. The Particles Field will interact with a Particles System if they both have matching Particles Field masks (one bit at least).
RETURNS:Current mask of the field. Integer, each bit of which is a mask.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ParticlesField.setViewportMask(int)
DESC:Sets a new Viewport mask enabling you to control rendering of the field. The Particles Field will be rendered in the viewport if it has a matching Viewport mask (one bit at least).
PARAMS:mask:New Viewport mask to be set for the field. Integer, each bit of which is a mask.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ParticlesField.getViewportMask const
DESC:Returns the current Viewport mask enabling you to control rendering of the field. The Particles Field will be rendered in the viewport if it has a matching Viewport mask (one bit at least).
RETURNS:Current Viewport mask of the field. Integer, each bit of which is a mask.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ParticlesField.INTERACT_PARTICLE_MODE_POSITION
DESC:Position mode. Interaction between the Particles Field and a particle takes place if the position of the particle's center comes into contact (intersection) with the field (its volume or surface in case of a deflector field).
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ParticlesField.INTERACT_PARTICLE_MODE_BOUND
DESC:Bound mode. Interaction between the Particles Field and a particle takes place if the bounding box of the particle comes into contact (intersection) with the field (its volume or surface in case of a deflector field).
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.ParticlesField.NUM_INTERACT_PARTICLE_MODES
DESC:Number of interaction modes for Particles Fields.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ParticlesFieldDeflector.#ctor
DESC:Constructor. Creates a new Particles Field Deflector with default parameters.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ParticlesFieldDeflector.#ctor(Unigine.Math.vec2)
DESC:Constructor. Creates a new Particles Field Deflector of the specified size.
PARAMS:size:Size of the Particles Field Deflector along the X and Y axes, in units.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ParticlesFieldDeflector.type
DESC:Returns the type of the Particles Field Deflector node.
RETURNS:ParticlesFieldDeflector type identifier.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ParticlesFieldDeflector.setSize(Unigine.Math.vec2)
DESC:Sets a new size of the Particles Field Deflector along the X and Y axes. Deflectors are represented as planes.
PARAMS:size:New size of the Particles Field Deflector along the X and Y axes to be set in units.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ParticlesFieldDeflector.getSize const
DESC:Returns the current size of the Particles Field Deflector along the X and Y axes. Deflectors are represented as planes.
RETURNS:Current size of the Particles Field Deflector along the X and Y axes.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ParticlesFieldDeflector.setRoughness(float)
DESC:Sets a new roughness coefficient for the Particles Field Deflector. This coefficient defines roughness of the deflector surface the particles collide with, and the range of angles at which particles shall bounce from the deflector.
PARAMS:roughness:New roughness coefficient for the deflector:The minimum value of 0 means the surface is smooth and bouncing particles are scattered in a uniform direction.The maximum value of 1 means the surface is uneven and bouncing particles are scattered in different directions.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ParticlesFieldDeflector.getRoughness const
DESC:Returns the current roughness coefficient for the Particles Field Deflector. This coefficient defines roughness of the deflector surface the particles collide with, and the range of angles at which particles shall bounce from the deflector.
RETURNS:Current roughness coefficient of the deflector:The minimum value of 0 means the surface is smooth and bouncing particles are scattered in a uniform direction.The maximum value of 1 means the surface is uneven and bouncing particles are scattered in different directions.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ParticlesFieldDeflector.setRestitution(float)
DESC:Sets a new restitution coefficient for the Particles Field Deflector. This coefficient defines the value of the bouncing impulse a particle will receive on a contact with the deflector (how fast a particle shall bounce from the deflector).
PARAMS:restitution:New restitution coefficient for the deflector:The minimum value of 0 means the particles do not bounce off, but rather slide along deflector surface.The maximum value of 1 makes the angle of bouncing equal to the angle at which the particles fall.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.ParticlesFieldDeflector.getRestitution const
DESC:Returns the current restitution coefficient for the Particles Field Deflector. This coefficient defines the value of the bouncing impulse a particle will receive on a contact with the deflector (how fast a particle shall bounce from the deflector).
RETURNS:Current restitution coefficient of the deflector:The minimum value of 0 means the particles do not bounce off, but rather slide along deflector surface.The maximum value of 1 makes the angle of bouncing equal to the angle at which the particles fall.
-

DESC:Sets a new size for the Particles Field Spacer.
PARAMS:size:New size of the Particles Field Spacer along the X, Y, and Z axes to be set, in units. In case the spacer has an ellipse shape, each component of the vector sets a radius along the corresponding axis.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Path.getAngularVelocity(float,int)
DESC:Returns the angular velocity of the object moving along the path at the specified time. If the path is non-looped and the specified time is bigger than the current path time, the last path position will be returned. If the path is looped, several loops can be used to count off time.
PARAMS:time:Time in seconds. | loop:Flag indicating if the path is looped. The default is 0 (path isn't looped).
RETURNS:Angular velocity. If the number of frames is equal to 0 or 1, the function returns the (0,0,0) vector.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Path.getFrameScale(int)

PARAMS:navigation:Navigation area

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Navigation.inside2D(Unigine.Math.Vec3,float)
DESC:Depending on the type of the navigation area, the function performs the following: For navigation sectors, it checks whether the given point is inside the navigation sector. The height of the navigation sector (Z coordinate) is ignored. For navigation meshes, it checks whether the given point is inside the navigation mesh and the distance from the point to the mesh is in range [-height;height]. Here height is a height of the navigation mesh.
PARAMS:point:Point coordinates. | radius:The radius of the point. The radius is used to exclude exceeding the navigation mesh by the point.If the radius is set, it is more likely that the point will be inside the navigation mesh.When calling the function for NavigationSector, this option is irrelevant.
RETURNS:1 if the point is inside the navigation area; otherwise, 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Navigation.inside3D(Unigine.Math.Vec3,float)
DESC:Depending on the type of the navigation area, the function performs the following: For navigation sectors, it checks whether the given point is inside the navigation area. Notice that the height of the navigation sector (Z coordinate) is also taken into account. For navigation meshes, it checks whether the given point is inside the navigation mesh and the distance from the point to the mesh is in range [0;height]. Here height is a height of the navigation mesh.
PARAMS:point:Point coordinates. | radius:The radius of the point. The radius is used to exclude exceeding the navigation mesh by the point.If the radius is set, it is more likely that the point will be inside the navigation mesh.When calling the function for NavigationSector, this option is irrelevant.
RETURNS:1 it the point is inside the navigation area; otherwise, 0.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Physics.getIntersection(Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Math.Vec3,int,Unigine.Vector{Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Node},int,Unigine.VectorAllocator},Unigine.Ptr{PhysicsIntersection})
DESC:Performs tracing from the p0 point to the p1 point to find a collision object located on that line. If an object is assigned a body, intersection occurs with its shape. If an object has no body, this function detects intersection with surfaces (polygons) of objects with intersection flag set. Intersection is found only for objects with a matching mask if their ID is not found in the exclude list. Intersection does not work for disabled objects. This function uses world space coordinates.
PARAMS:p0:Line start point coordinates. | p1:Line end point coordinates. | mask:Physics intersection mask. If 0 is passed, the function will return NULL. | exclude:Array of nodes to be excluded. | intersection:PhysicsIntersection class instance containing intersection data.
RETURNS:The first intersected object, if found; otherwise, 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Physics.getIntersection(Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Math.Vec3,int,Unigine.Vector{Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Node},int,Unigine.VectorAllocator},Unigine.Vector{Shape::TYPE,int,Unigine.VectorAllocator},Unigine.Ptr{PhysicsIntersection})
DESC:Performs tracing from the p0 point to the p1 point to find a collision object located on that line. If an object is assigned a body, intersection occurs with its shape. If an object has no body, this function detects intersection with surfaces (polygons) of objects with intersection flag set. Intersection is found only for objects with a matching mask if their ID is not found in the exclude list and only for shape types not mentioned in the exclude_types list. Intersection does not work for disabled objects. This function uses world space coordinates.
PARAMS:p0:Line start point coordinates. | p1:Line end point coordinates. | mask:Physics intersection mask. If 0 is passed, the function will return NULL. | exclude:Array of nodes to be excluded. | exclude_types:Array of shape types to be excluded. | intersection:PhysicsIntersection class instance containing intersection data.
RETURNS:The first intersected object, if found; otherwise, 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Physics.getIntersection(Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Math.Vec3,int,Unigine.Ptr{PhysicsIntersection})
DESC:Performs tracing from the p0 point to the p1 point to find a collision object located on that line. If an object is assigned a body, intersection occurs with its shape. If an object has no body, this function detects intersection with surfaces (polygons) of objects with intersection flag set. Physics intersection shall only be detected for objects with a matching mask. Intersection does not work for disabled objects. This function uses world space coordinates. Usage Example The following example shows how you can get the intersection information by using the PhysicsIntersection class. In this example the line is an invisible traced line from the point of the camera (vec3 p0) to the point of the mouse pointer (vec3 p1). The executing sequence is the following: Define and initialize two points (p0 and p1) by using the Player::getDirectionFromScreen() function. Create an instance of the PhysicsIntersection class to get the intersection information. Check, if there is an intersection with an object. The getIntersection() function returns an intersected object when the object intersects with the traced line. When the object intersects with the traced line, all the surfaces of the intersected object change their material parameters. If the object has a shape, its information will be shown in the console. The PhysicsIntersection class instance gets the coordinates of the intersection point and the Shape class object. You can get all these fields by using getShape(), getPoint() functions.
PARAMS:p0:Line start point coordinates. | p1:Line end point coordinates. | mask:Physics intersection mask. If 0 is passed, the function will return NULL. | intersection:PhysicsIntersection class instance containing intersection data.
RETURNS:The first intersected object, if found; otherwise, 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Physics.getIntersection(Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Math.Vec3,int,Unigine.Ptr{PhysicsIntersectionNormal})

If an object has no body, this function detects intersection with surfaces (polygons) of objects with intersection flag set. Physics intersection shall only be detected for objects with a matching mask. Intersection does not work for disabled objects. This function uses world space coordinates.
PARAMS:p0:Line start point coordinates. | p1:Line end point coordinates. | mask:Physics intersection mask. If 0 is passed, the function will return NULL. | intersection:PhysicsIntersectionNormal class instance containing intersection data.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Physics.setDeterminism(bool)
DESC:Sets a value indicating if objects are updated in a definite order or not. Deterministic mode ensures that all contacts are solved in the predefined order and visualization of physics in the world is repetitive (on one computer). When this mode is enabled the Engine performs additional sorting of bodies, shapes and joints inside islands after building them. Deterministic mode is unavailable in case there are missed frames — it is simply impossible. Moreover, there may be differences between visualization of physics on different hardware (e.g., AMD and Intel). Determinism is guaranteed if there are no missed frames, the same Engine version is used, and the CPUs perform SSE operations similarly.Please note that deterministic mode does not come for free, it may eat up 10-20% of the frame rate, and it also depends on the scene a lot.
PARAMS:determinism:true to indicate that the objects are updated in a definite order; false to indicate that an objects update order may change. The default is false (the update order may change).
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Physics.isDeterminism const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if objects are updated in a definite order or not.Deterministic mode ensures that all contacts are solved in the predefined order and visualization of physics in the world is repetitive (on one computer). When this mode is enabled the Engine performs additional sorting of bodies, shapes and joints inside islands after building them. Deterministic mode is unavailable in case there are missed frames — it is simply impossible. Moreover, there may be differences between visualization of physics on different hardware (e.g., AMD and Intel). Determinism is guaranteed if there are no missed frames, the same Engine version is used, and the CPUs perform SSE operations similarly.Please note that deterministic mode does not come for free, it may eat up 10-20% of the frame rate, and it also depends on the scene a lot.
RETURNS:true if the objects are updated in a definite order; otherwise false. The default is false (the update order may change).

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Physics.setStableFPS(bool)
DESC:Returns a value indicating if frame time stabilization is enabled. In case the current Engine framerate is much higher than the fixed Physics framerate (e.g. 120 FPS vs 60 FPS), the physics won't be updated each rendering frame (e.g. it may update during every second frame). The resulting frame time will become unstable, shorter-longer-shorter-longer (render -> render+physics -> render -> render+physics...). This option ensures stable frame time for smoother user experience removing unwanted "hiccups" (however, the average framerate is decreased).By default, this option is enabled. But you can disable it to increase average framerate in case the application is used for machine learning or for grabbing frame sequences (video grabber), when smoothness is not important.
PARAMS:stablefps:true to enable frame time stabilization; false — to disable it.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Physics.isStableFPS const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if frame time stabilization is enabled. In case the current Engine framerate is much higher than the fixed Physics framerate (e.g. 120 FPS vs 60 FPS), the physics won't be updated each rendering frame (e.g. it may update during every second frame). The resulting frame time will become unstable, shorter-longer-shorter-longer (render -> render+physics -> render -> render+physics...). This option ensures stable frame time for smoother user experience removing unwanted "hiccups" (however, the average framerate is decreased).By default, this option is enabled. But you can disable it to increase average framerate in case the application is used for machine learning or for grabbing frame sequences (video grabber), when smoothness is not important.
RETURNS:true if frame time stabilization is enabled; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Physics.setUpdateMode(Physics::UPDATE_MODE)
DESC:Sets the update mode to be used for physics. Physics can be updated either asynchronously (in parallel with rendering) or in the Main thread before rendering. The async mode is the fastest one and is used by default, however, it has a one-frame lag (calculation results are applied in the next frame) and some nuances regarding user code execution in some cases.
PARAMS:mode:New physics update mode to be set.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Physics.getUpdateMode const
DESC:Returns the current physics update mode. Physics can be updated either asynchronously (in parallel with rendering) or in the Main thread before rendering. The async mode is the fastest one and is used by default, however, it has a one-frame lag (calculation results are applied in the next frame) and some nuances regarding user code execution in some cases.
RETURNS:Current physics update mode.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Physics.setMissedFrameLifetime(float)
DESC:Sets the lifetime for missed frames. This value defines how long missed frames are to be kept in the catch-up buffer. In case the current Engine framerate is lower than the fixed Physics framerate, some of the physics frames get skipped and the simulation starts looking like in a slo-mo effect (e.g., if the target physics framerate is 60 FPS, when the Engine updates at 30 FPS, the simulation will look 2 times slower). The Physics module will try to catch up everything missed later, when possible (e.g. when the Engine framerate grows higher, while waiting for GPU to complete rendering). The missed frames are kept in a buffer for some time (lifetime), as it expires the frame is removed from the buffer and becomes lost forever.
PARAMS:lifetime:Lifetime for missing frame, in milliseconds. Setting too high values may result in significant memory consumption in case of low hardware capabilities (no catching-up performed with a growing number of missed frames).
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Physics.getMissedFrameLifetime const
DESC:Sets the lifetime for missed frames. This value defines how long missed frames are to be kept in the catch-up buffer. In case the current Engine framerate is lower than the fixed Physics framerate, some of the physics frames get skipped and the simulation starts looking like in a slo-mo effect (e.g., if the target physics framerate is 60 FPS, when the Engine updates at 30 FPS, the simulation will look 2 times slower). The Physics module will try to catch up everything missed later, when possible (e.g. when the Engine framerate grows higher, while waiting for GPU to complete rendering). The missed frames are kept in a buffer for some time (lifetime), as it expires the frame is removed from the buffer and becomes lost forever.
RETURNS:Lifetime for missing frame, in milliseconds. Setting too high values may result in significant memory consumption in case of low hardware capabilities (no catching-up performed with a growing number of missed frames).

ENTRY:F:Unigine.Physics.UPDATE_MODE_BEFORE_RENDERING
DESC:Update Before Rendering. Physics update (along with the spatial tree update and user callbacks) is executed in the Main thread just before rendering is performed (render). The number of physics ticks executed before the rendering frame here is defined by the physics and the Engine framerates. This mode is the most clear and straightforward (everything is executed safely in a strictly determined order) with no frame lag (results of physics calculations are applied in the current frame). But, on the other hand, this mode is the slowest as there are no asynchronous parallel calculations (everything's in the Main thread). Use this mode in case the time lag is unacceptabe for your application (you need all physics calculations to be applied in the current frame) and you want maximum simplicity and strictly determined order of execution for user code (physicsUpdate and physics callbacks).
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.Physics.UPDATE_MODE_ASYNC_RENDERING
DESC:Asynchronous update mode. Physics update is performed asynchronously to rendering. In case of several physics ticks per one rendering frame (when the Engine framerate is lower, or catching up is performed), only the first one is executed in parallel, then the physics module waits for the completion of the rendering process, returns to the Main thread and executes the rest of the physics ticks. There is a frame lag (results of physics calculations are applied in the next frame) and there is some ambiguity regarding the time, when user code (physicsUpdate and physics callbacks) is to be executed in case of several physics ticks per one rendering frame (some part is executed before rendering while the other just after it). This mode is the fastest one and is used by default.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Body.isContactInternal(int) const
DESC:Returns a value indicating whether the contact with the specified number is internal (handled by the body) or not (handled by another body). A contact can be handled by any of the bodies that participate in it. To which body a contact is assigned is random. If the contact is assigned to and handled by the body it is called an internal one, otherwise it is called external (handled by another body). The total number of contacts for the body includes all, internal and external ones. Iterating through internal contacts is much faster than through external ones, thus you might want a certain body to handle most of the contacts it participates in. This can be done for a rigid body by raising a priority for the body via .
PARAMS:num:Contact number in the range from 0 to the total number of contacts.
RETURNS:true if the contact with the specified number is internal; otherwise false.
-

ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyFracture.addForce(Unigine.Math.vec3) const
DESC:Applies a force to the center of mass of the body. Unlike impulses, all forces are accumulated first, then the resulting force is calculated and applied to the body (during the physics simulation stage, when the body update() function is called). You can call this function only from updatePhysics() function in the world script. Do not apply forces in the update() function, because you will get unstable result that varies each rendering frame.
PARAMS:force:Force to be applied, in world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyFracture.addForce(Unigine.Math.vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3) const
DESC:Applies a force to a point determined by a given radius vector, specified in the local coordinates. This function calculates the cross product of the radius vector and the force vector. It acts like a lever arm that changes both linear and angular velocities of the body. Unlike impulses, all forces are accumulated first, then the resulting force is calculated and applied to the body (during the physics simulation stage, when the body update() function is called). You can call this function only from updatePhysics() function in the world script. Do not apply forces in the update() function, because you will get unstable result that varies each rendering frame.
PARAMS:radius:Radius vector, traced from the center of mass of the body to the point where the force is applied, in local coordinates. | force:Force to be applied, in world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyFracture.addImpulse(Unigine.Math.vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3)
DESC:Applies an impulse to a point determined by a given radius vector, specified in the local coordinates. Unlike forces, impulses immediately affect both linear and angular velocities of the body.
PARAMS:radius:Radius vector, traced from the center of mass to the point where the impulse is applied, in local coordinates. | impulse:Impulse to be applied, in world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyFracture.addTorque(Unigine.Math.vec3) const
DESC:Applies a torque with a pivot point at the center of mass of the body, specified in the local coordinates. All torque values are accumulated first, then the resulting torque is calculated and applied to the body (during the physics simulation stage, when the body update is called). You can call this function only from updatePhysics() function in the world script. Do not apply torques in the update() function, because you will get unstable result that varies each rendering frame.
PARAMS:torque:Torque to be applied, in world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyFracture.addTorque(Unigine.Math.vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3) const
DESC:Applies a torque with a pivot point, determined by a given radius vector, specified in the local coordinates. This function calculates the cross product of the radius vector and the force vector. It acts like a lever arm that changes both angular and linear velocities of the body. All torque values are accumulated first, then the resulting torque is calculated and applied to the body (during the physics simulation stage, when the body update is called). You can call this function only from updatePhysics() function in the world script. Do not apply torques in the update() function, because you will get unstable result that varies each rendering frame.
PARAMS:radius:Radius vector starting at the body's center of mass, in local coordinates. Its end is the pivot point for the torque to be applied. | torque:Torque to be applied, in world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyFracture.addWorldForce(Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3)
DESC:Applies a force to a given point of the body that is specified in world coordinates. This function calculates the cross product of the radius vector (a vector from the center of mass to the point where force is applied) and the force vector. It acts like a lever arm that changes both linear and angular velocities of the body. Unlike impulses, all forces are accumulated first, then the resulting force is calculated and applied to the body (during the physics simulation stage, when the body update is called). You can call this function only from updatePhysics() function in the world script. Do not apply forces in the update() function, because you will get unstable result that varies each rendering frame.
PARAMS:point:Point of the body in world coordinates. | force:Force to be applied, in world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyFracture.addWorldImpulse(Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3)
DESC:Applies an impulse to a given point of the body, that is specified in world coordinates. Unlike forces, impulses immediately affect both linear and angular velocities of the body.
PARAMS:point:Point of the body in world coordinates. | impulse:Impulse to be applied, in world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyFracture.addWorldTorque(Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3)
DESC:Applies a torque with a pivot point at a given point of the body, that is specified in world coordinates. This function calculates the cross product of the radius vector (a vector from the center of mass to the pivot point) and the torque vector. It acts like a lever arm that changes both angular and linear velocities of the body. All torque values are accumulated first, then the resulting torque is calculated and applied to the body (during the physics simulation stage, when the body update is called). You can call this function only from updatePhysics() function in the world script. Do not apply torques in the update() function, because you will get unstable result that varies each rendering frame.
PARAMS:point:Point of the body in world coordinates. | torque:Torque to be applied, in world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyFracture.createCrackPieces(Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3,int,int,float)
DESC:Breaks the object into radial cracks combined with concentric splits. If the first concentric split is rendered further than the specified step distance, decrease the volume threshold value.
PARAMS:point:Point of contact. | normal:Normal of the contact point. | num_cuts:Number of radial cuts that are represented as rays coming from the center of contact point. | num_rings:Number of rings that form concentric splits. The number of rings that is will be actually rendered depends on the step value. | step:Distance between concentric splits.
RETURNS:Positive number if the object was successfully broken; otherwise, 0.
-

DESC:Breaks the object into arbitrary shattered pieces.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyFracture.createSlicePieces(Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3)
DESC:Breaks the object into two slices, slitting the body according to the normal of the specified point.
PARAMS:point:Point of contact. | normal:Normal of the contact point.
RETURNS:Positive number if the object was successfully broken; otherwise, 0.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyParticles.setIterationsMode(BodyParticles::ITERATIONS_MODE)
DESC:Sets iteration mode to be used for the particles body. The mode determines how the number of iterations for solving the constraints of the particles body is calculated. This method adds flexibility in fine-tuning of performance and simulation quality for each particles body.
PARAMS:mode:Iteration mode to be used for the particles body:OVERRIDE - the resulting number of iterations is equal to the value set for the body.MULTIPLICATION - the resulting number of iterations is equal to the value set for the body multiplied by the global physics iterations number.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyParticles.getIterationsMode const
DESC:Returns the current iteration mode to be used for the particles body. The mode determines how the number of iterations for solving the constraints of the particles body is calculated. This method adds flexibility in fine-tuning of performance and simulation quality for each particles body.
RETURNS:Current iteration mode of the particles body:OVERRIDE - the resulting number of iterations is equal to the value set for the body.MULTIPLICATION - the resulting number of iterations is equal to the value set for the body multiplied by the global physics iterations number.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.BodyParticles.ITERATIONS_MODE_MULTIPLICATION
DESC:In this mode the resulting number of iterations is equal to the value set for the body multiplied by the global physics iterations number.
-
ENTRY:F:Unigine.BodyParticles.ITERATIONS_MODE_OVERRIDE
DESC:In this mode the resulting number of iterations is equal to the Iterations value set for the body.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyRagdoll.createBones(float,float,int)
DESC:Automatically generates a simplified skeleton from the mesh and its bones. Each bone is approximated with a convex hull or a capsule based on given parameters.
PARAMS:error:Permissible error, which is used for creating convex hulls. This is an optional parameter. | threshold:Threshold, which is used to detect and discard too small convex hulls. A convex hull, which volume is smaller than an average volume multiplied by the threshold, is discarded. This is an optional parameter. | capsule:Approximation shape. By the value of 0, convex hull is used; the value of 1 sets capsule approximation.
RETURNS:Created bone number.
