ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyRigid.addForce(Unigine.Math.vec3)
DESC:Applies a force to the center of mass of the body. Unlike impulses, all forces are accumulated first, then the resulting force is calculated and applied to the body (during the physics simulation stage, when the body update() function is called). You can call this function only from updatePhysics() function in the world script. Do not apply forces in the update() function, because you will get unstable result that varies each rendering frame.
PARAMS:force:Force to be applied, in world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyRigid.addForce(Unigine.Math.vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3)
DESC:Applies a force to a point determined by a given radius vector, specified in the local coordinates. This function calculates the cross product of the radius vector and the force vector. It acts like a lever arm that changes both linear and angular velocities of the body. Unlike impulses, all forces are accumulated first, then the resulting force is calculated and applied to the body (during the physics simulation stage, when the body update() function is called). You can call this function only from updatePhysics() function in the world script. Do not apply forces in the update() function, because you will get unstable result that varies each rendering frame.
PARAMS:radius:Radius vector, traced from the center of mass of the body to the point where the force is applied. | force:Force to be applied, in world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyRigid.addImpulse(Unigine.Math.vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3)
DESC:Applies an impulse to a point determined by a given radius vector, specified in the local coordinates. Unlike forces, impulses immediately affect both linear and angular velocities of the body.
PARAMS:radius:Radius vector, traced from the center of mass to the point where the impulse is applied. | impulse:Impulse to be applied, in world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyRigid.addLinearImpulse(Unigine.Math.vec3)
DESC:Applies an impulse similar to the addImpulse() method, but affects only the linear velocity.
PARAMS:impulse:Impulse to be applied, in world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyRigid.addAngularImpulse(Unigine.Math.vec3)
DESC:Applies an impulse similar to the addImpulse() method, but affects only the angular velocity.
PARAMS:impulse:Impulse to be applied, in world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyRigid.addTorque(Unigine.Math.vec3)
DESC:Applies a torque with a pivot point at the center of mass of the body, specified in the local coordinates. All torque values are accumulated first, then the resulting torque is calculated and applied to the body (during the physics simulation stage, when the body update is called). You can call this function only from updatePhysics() function in the world script. Do not apply forces in the update() function, because you will get unstable result that varies each rendering frame.
PARAMS:torque:Torque to be applied, in world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyRigid.addTorque(Unigine.Math.vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3)
DESC:Applies a torque with a pivot point, determined by a given radius vector, specified in the local coordinates. This function calculates the cross product of the radius vector and the force vector. It acts like a lever arm that changes both angular and linear velocities of the body. All torque values are accumulated first, then the resulting torque is calculated and applied to the body (during the physics simulation stage, when the body update is called). You can call this function only from updatePhysics() function in the world script. Do not apply torques in the update() function, because you will get unstable result that varies each rendering frame.
PARAMS:radius:Radius vector starting at the body's center of mass. Its end is the pivot point for the torque to be applied. | torque:Torque to be applied, in world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyRigid.addWorldForce(Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3)
DESC:Applies a force to a given point of the body that is specified in world coordinates. This function calculates the cross product of the radius vector (a vector from the center of mass to the point where force is applied) and the force vector. It acts like a lever arm that changes both linear and angular velocities of the body. Unlike impulses, all forces are accumulated first, then the resulting force is calculated and applied to the body (during the physics simulation stage, when the body update is called). You can call this function only from updatePhysics() function in the world script. Do not apply forces in the update() function, because you will get unstable result that varies each rendering frame.
PARAMS:point:Point of the body, in world coordinates. | force:Force to be applied, in world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyRigid.addWorldImpulse(Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3)
DESC:Applies an impulse to a given point of the body, that is specified in world coordinates. Unlike forces, impulses immediately affect both linear and angular velocities of the body.
PARAMS:point:Point of the body, in world coordinates. | impulse:Impulse to be applied, in world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyRigid.addWorldTorque(Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3)
DESC:Applies a torque with a pivot point at a given point of the body, that is specified in world coordinates. This function calculates the cross product of the radius vector (a vector from the center of mass to the pivot point) and the torque vector. It acts like a lever arm that changes both angular and linear velocities of the body. All torque values are accumulated first, then the resulting torque is calculated and applied to the body (during the physics simulation stage, when the body update is called). You can call this function only from updatePhysics() function in the world script. Do not apply torques in the update() function, because you will get unstable result that varies each rendering frame.
PARAMS:point:Point of the body, in world coordinates. | torque:Torque to be applied, in world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BodyRigid.createShapes(int,float,float)
DESC:Removes all previously created shapes and creates one or more convex shapes approximating the mesh.
PARAMS:depth:Degree of decomposition of the mesh. If 0 or a negative value is provided, only one shape will be created. If a positive n is provided, the mesh will be decomposed n times. This is an optional parameter. | error:Approximation error, which is used to create convex hulls. This is an optional parameter. | threshold:Threshold, which is used to decide, whether two adjoining convex shapes can be replaced with one larger shape. A pair of shapes is replaced with a larger shape, if their volumes are roughly the same. This value is clamped in the range [1 E-6; 1]. This is an optional parameter.
RETURNS:1 if the convex shapes are created successfully; otherwise 0.

DESC:Saves the state of a given node into a binary stream. If a node is a parent for other nodes, states of these child nodes need to be saved manually. To save the state from a buffer, file or a message from a socket, make sure the stream is opened. For buffers and files, you also need to set the proper position for reading. Example using saveState() and restoreState() methods:
PARAMS:stream:Stream to save node state data.
RETURNS:true if the node state is saved successfully; otherwise, false.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Joint.restoreState(Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Stream})
DESC:Restores the state of a given node from a binary stream. If a node is a parent for other nodes, states of these child nodes need to be restored manually. To save the state into a buffer, file or a message from a socket, make sure the stream is opened. If necessary, you can set a position for writing for buffers and files. Example using saveState() and restoreState() methods:
PARAMS:stream:Stream with saved node state data.
RETURNS:true if the node state is restored successfully; otherwise, false.

DESC:Performs collision check for the shape and puts information on all contacts to the output buffer. Collisions with the surface can be found only if the following conditions are fulfilled: The surface is enabled. Per-surface Collision flag is enabled. The surface has a material assigned. The shape must be enabled.

Collisions with the surface can be found only if the following conditions are fulfilled: The surface is enabled. Per-surface Collision flag is enabled. The surface has a material assigned. The shape must be enabled.
PARAMS:object:Object to be ignored when detecting collisions. This parameter is used when it is necessary to ignore collisions of the shape with the object it belongs to. | contacts:Output buffer containing information on all detected physical contacts for the shape (if any). Information on each contact can be handled via the ShapeContact class. | ifps:Inverse FPS value.
RETURNS:1 if collisions are found; otherwise, 0.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Shape.getIntersection(Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Ptr{PhysicsIntersectionNormal}) const
DESC:Performs tracing from the p0 point to the p1 point to find a shape intersected by this line. Intersection is found only for objects with a matching intersection mask. World space coordinates are used for this function.
PARAMS:p0:Start point of the line. | p1:End point of the line. | intersection:PhysicsIntersectionNormal class instance containing intersection information
RETURNS:1 if an intersection was detected; otherwise - 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Shape.getIntersection(Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Ptr{PhysicsIntersection}) const
DESC:Performs tracing from the p0 point to the p1 point to find a shape intersected by this line. Intersection is found only for objects with a matching intersection mask. World space coordinates are used for this function. Usage Example The following example shows how you can get the intersection information by using the PhysicsIntersection class. In this example the line is an invisible traced line from the point of the camera (vec3 p0) to the point of the mouse pointer (vec3 p1). It is supposed that you have a dynamic mesh with a body and a shape assigned. The executing sequence is the following: Define and initialize two points (p0 and p1) by using the Player::getDirectionFromScreen() function. Create an instance of the PhysicsIntersection class to get the information of the intersection point. Check, if there is a intersection with a shape and save the result in the integer variable. In this example, if there is an intersection of mouse direction with a shape, the PhysicsIntersection class instance gets the intersection point. The result is shown in the console.
PARAMS:p0:Start point of the line. | p1:End point of the line. | intersection:PhysicsIntersection class instance containing intersection information.
RETURNS:1 if an intersection was detected; otherwise - 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Shape.getIntersection(Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Math.vec3) const
DESC:Performs tracing from the p0 point to the p1 point to find a shape intersected by this line. Intersection is found only for objects with a matching intersection mask. World space coordinates are used for this function.
PARAMS:p0:Start point of the line (in world coordinates). | p1:End point of the line (in world coordinates). | ret_point:Container to which contact point coordinates (if any) shall be put (in world coordinate system). | ret_normal:Container to which contact point normal coordinates (if any) shall be put (in world coordinate system).
RETURNS:1 if an intersection was detected; otherwise - 0.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setFov(float)
DESC:Sets a vertical field of view of the player. Horizontal FOV cannot be used since it varies depending on the viewport's aspect ratio. Setting FOV recalculates projection matrix with aspect ratio = 1. You can use the following formula to calculate horizontal FOV from the vertical one for the given aspect ratio (width/height): FOV_h = 2 × atan ( (width / height) × tan(FOV_v / 2)).
PARAMS:fov:New vertical field of view in degrees. The provided value will be saturated in the range [0; 180]. The default is 60 degrees.

You can use the following formula to calculate horizontal FOV from the vertical one for the given aspect ratio (width/height): FOV_h = 2 × atan ( (width / height) × tan(FOV_v / 2)).
RETURNS:Vertical field of view in degrees. The default is 60 degrees.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setObliqueFrustumPlane(Unigine.Math.Vec4)
DESC:Sets the oblique near clipping plane of the viewing frustum. This method does not affect the projection matrix. To enable the oblique frustum use the setObliqueFrustum() method.
PARAMS:plane:World coordinates of the oblique near clipping plane to set (Nx, Ny, Nz, D), where Nx, Ny, Nz - coordinates of the plane normal, D - distance from the origin to the plane.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getObliqueFrustumPlane const
DESC:Returns the oblique near clipping plane of the viewing frustum.
RETURNS:World coordinates of the oblique near clipping plane to set (Nx, Ny, Nz, D), where Nx, Ny, Nz - coordinates of the plane normal, D - distance from the origin to the plane.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setProjection(Unigine.Math.mat4)
DESC:Updates the current projection matrix. It is not recommended to use this method for setting obliqueness of the near clipping plane of the frustum, as in this case a number of features (such as clouds, shadows, TAA, a number of engine optimizations, etc.) will not function properly. Please, use the setObliqueFrustum() method instead.
PARAMS:projection:New projection matrix.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getProjection const
DESC:Returns the current projection matrix with unit (1.0) aspect ratio.
RETURNS:Current projection matrix.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getProjectionFromScreen(int,int,int,int,int,int) const
DESC:Creates a projection matrix out of 2 screen positions . This is required for the frame selection.
PARAMS:x0:X-coordinate of the first screen position. | y0:Y-coordinate of the first screen position. | x1:X-coordinate of the second screen position. | y1:Y-coordinate of the second screen position. | screen_width:Screen width. | screen_height:Screen height.
RETURNS:Projection matrix.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setReflectionViewportMask(int)
DESC:Sets a bit mask for rendering reflections into the viewport. Reflections are rendered in the viewport if masks of reflective materials match this one (one bit at least).
PARAMS:mask:Reflection viewport mask (an integer, each bit of which is a mask).
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getReflectionViewportMask const
DESC:Returns the current bit mask for rendering reflections into the viewport. Reflections are rendered in the viewport if masks of reflective materials match this one (one bit at least).
RETURNS:Reflection viewport mask (an integer, each bit of which is a mask).
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setReverbMask(int)
DESC:Sets a reverb mask that determines reverberation zones, which can be heard. For sound to reverberate, at least one bit of this mask should match with a reverb mask of the sound source and a reverb mask of the reverberation zone. Masks of a sound source and reverberation zone can match with the player's one in different bits, not necessarily one.
PARAMS:mask:Reverb mask (integer, each bit of which is a mask for reverberating sound sources and reverberation zones).
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getReverbMask const
DESC:Returns the current bit mask that determines what reverberation zones can be heard. For sound to reverberate, at least one bit of this mask should match with a reverb mask of the sound source and a reverb mask of the reverberation zone. (Masks of a sound source and reverberation zone can match with the player's one in different bits, not necessarily one).
RETURNS:Reverb mask (integer, each bit of which is a mask for reverberating sound sources and reverberation zones).
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getScreenPosition(int,int,Unigine.Math.Vec3,int,int) const
DESC:Projects the point in world coordinates to the screen. Screen coordinates are written into the first 2 variables passed to the method (in pixels).
PARAMS:x:X-coordinate of the screen position (in pixels). | y:Y-coordinate of the screen position (in pixels). | point:Point coordinates. | screen_width:Screen width. | screen_height:Screen height.
RETURNS:1 if the point has been projected successfully; otherwise, 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setSourceMask(int)
DESC:Sets a source mask that determines sound sources, which can be heard. For a sound source to be heard, its mask should match with this one in at least one bit. Plus, the volume of sound channel in which the sound plays (its number also depends on this mask) should not be equal to 0.
PARAMS:mask:Source mask (integer, each bit of which specifies a sound channel).
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getSourceMask const
DESC:Returns the source mask that determines sound sources, which can be heard. For a sound source to be heard, its mask should match with this one in at least one bit. Plus, the volume of sound channel in which the sound plays (its number also depends on this mask) should not be equal to 0.
RETURNS:Source mask (integer, each bit of which specifies a sound channel).
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setUp(Unigine.Math.vec3)
DESC:Sets an up direction of the player's viewport (i.e. tilt of the player's viewport). In case of PlayerActor, its transformation forces it to recalculate its inner state (position, direction, angles and so on), so the up direction of the player's viewport may become "negative forward". And then transformation will be recalculated by using this direction, causing flip of the basis of the player actor. To avoid such flipping, the theta and phi angles should be recalculated by using the current viewing orientation of the player.
PARAMS:up:New upward direction vector. The vector is normalized to 1.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getUp const
DESC:Returns the current up direction of the player's viewport (i.e. tilt of the player's viewport).
RETURNS:Upward direction vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setVelocity(Unigine.Math.vec3)
DESC:Sets a player's velocity. In case of PlayerActor, this function is valid only when the player is not simulated physically (setPhysical() is set to 0). If it is, moving PlayerActor is done via accessing its body.
PARAMS:velocity:New velocity in units per second.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getVelocity const
DESC:Returns the current velocity of the player.
RETURNS:Velocity in units per second.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setViewDirection(Unigine.Math.vec3)
DESC:Sets given view direction vector to the Player instance.
PARAMS:direction:A view direction vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getViewDirection const
DESC:Returns Player's view direction vector.
RETURNS:A view direction vector.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setViewportMask(int)
DESC:Sets a viewport mask. Object surfaces, materials, decals, lights and GUI objects will be rendered into the viewport only if their viewport mask matches the player's one (one matching bit is enough).
PARAMS:mask:Viewport mask (integer, each bit of which is a mask).
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getViewportMask const
DESC:Returns the current viewport mask. Object surfaces, materials, decals, lights and GUI objects will be rendered into the viewport only if their viewport mask matches the player's one (one matching bit is enough).
RETURNS:Viewport mask (integer, each bit of which is a mask).
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setZFar(float)
DESC:Sets a distance to the far clipping plane of the player's viewing frustum. The default is 10000 units.
PARAMS:zfar:Distance to the far clipping plane in units. The minimum value is 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getZFar const
DESC:Returns the current distance to the far clipping plane of the player's viewing frustum. The default is 10000 units.
RETURNS:Distance to the far clipping plane in units.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setZNear(float)
DESC:Sets a distance to the near clipping plane of the player's viewing frustum. The default is 0.1 units.
PARAMS:znear:Distance to the near clipping plane in units. The minimum value is 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getZNear const
DESC:Returns the distance to the near clipping plane of the player's viewing frustum. The default is 0.1 units.
RETURNS:Distance to the near clipping plane in units.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.flushTransform const
DESC:Forces to immediately set transformations to the player. This function should be called manually after user input has been updated via updateControls().
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.updateControls(float) const
DESC:Gets the current player's parameters (impulse, direction, velocity etc) according to user input. After the input has been updated, flushTransform() should be called manually to apply it to the player.
PARAMS:ifps:Frame duration in seconds.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setFovMode(Camera::FOV_MODE)
DESC:Sets the value indicating the type of FOV that is used for the player: For the standard player, the vertical FOV should be set. In this case, FOV is directly set in degrees. For the physically-based player, the horizontal FOV should be set. In this case, FOV is calculated depending on the film gate and focal length of the player.
PARAMS:mode:FOV_MODE_VERTICAL for the player with the vertical FOV; FOV_MODE_PHYSICALLY_BASED_CAMERA for the physically-based player with the horizontal FOV.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getFovMode const
DESC:Returns the value indicating the type of FOV that is used for the player.
RETURNS:0 if the player with the vertical FOV is used; 1 if the physically-based player with the horizontal FOV is used.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setFilmGate(float)
DESC:Sets a film gate for the physically-based camera with horizontal FOV.
PARAMS:gate:Film gate.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getFilmGate const
DESC:Returns a film gate for the physically-based camera with horizontal FOV.
RETURNS:Film gate.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setFocalLength(float)
DESC:Sets a focal length of the physically-based camera lens.
PARAMS:length:Camera lens focal length.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getFocalLength const
DESC:Returns the focal length of the physically-based camera lens.
RETURNS:Camera lens focal length.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getAspectCorrectedProjection(int,int) const
DESC:Returns projection matrix after correction for the specified aspect ratio (screen width / screen height). Currently fixed FOV component is taken into account.
PARAMS:width:Screen width. | height:Screen height.
RETURNS:Projection matrix after correction for the specified aspect ratio (screen width / screen height).
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getFovFixed const
DESC:Returns a value indicating which FOV component (horizontal or vertical) is currently fixed.
RETURNS:Current fixed FOV component, one of the Camera::FOV_FIXED_* values.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.addScriptableMaterial(Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Material})
DESC:Attaches a new scriptable material to the player. To apply a scriptable material globally, use the method of the Render class. The order of execution for scripts assigned to scriptable materials is defined by material's number in the list of the player.Scriptable materials applied globally have their expressions executed before the ones that are applied per-player.
PARAMS:material:Scriptable material to be attached to the player.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.insertScriptableMaterial(int,Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Material})
DESC:Inserts a new scriptable material into the list of the ones assigned to the player. To apply a scriptable material globally, use the insertScriptableMaterial() method of the Render class. The order of execution for scripts assigned to scriptable materials is defined by material's number in the player's list.Scriptable materials applied globally have their expressions executed before the ones that are applied per-player.
PARAMS:num:Position at which a new scriptable material is to be inserted. | material:Scriptable material to be inserted.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.removeScriptableMaterial(int)
DESC:Removes the scriptable material with the specified number from the player.
PARAMS:num:Scriptable material number in the range from 0 to the total number of scriptable materials.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getNumScriptableMaterials const
DESC:Returns the total number of scriptable materials attached to the player.
RETURNS:Total number of scriptable materials attached to the player.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.findScriptableMaterial(Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Material}) const
DESC:Returns the number of the specified scriptable material for the player. This number is player-specific (valid for this player only) and determines the order in which the assigned expressions are executed. Scriptable materials applied globally have their expressions executed before the ones that are applied per-player.
PARAMS:material:Scriptable material for which a number is to be found.
RETURNS:Scriptable material number in the range from 0 to the total number of scriptable materials, or -1 if the specified material was not found.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setScriptableMaterial(int,Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Material})
DESC:Replaces the scriptable material with the specified number with the new scriptable material specified. The number of material determines the order in which the expressions assigned to it are executed. This number is player-specific (valid for this player only). Scriptable materials applied globally have their expressions executed before the ones that are applied per-player.
PARAMS:num:Scriptable material number in the range from 0 to the total number of scriptable materials. | material:New scriptable material to replace the one with the specified number.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getScriptableMaterial(int) const
DESC:Returns a scriptable material attached to the player by its number.
PARAMS:num:Scriptable material number in the range from 0 to the total number of scriptable materials.
RETURNS:Scriptable material attached to the player with the specified number.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setScriptableMaterialEnabled(int,bool)
DESC:Enables or disables the scriptable material with the specified number. When a material is disabled (inactive), the scripts attached to it are not executed.
PARAMS:num:Scriptable material number in the range from 0 to the total number of scriptable materials. | enabled:true to enable the scriptable material with the specified number, false to disable it.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getScriptableMaterialEnabled(int) const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if the scriptable material with the specified number attached to the player is enabled (active). When a material is disabled (inactive), the scripts attached to it are not executed.
PARAMS:num:Scriptable material number in the range from 0 to the total number of scriptable materials.
RETURNS:true if the scriptable material with the specified number is enabled; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.swapScriptableMaterials(int,int)
DESC:Swaps two scriptable materials with specified numbers. The number of material determines the order in which the expressions assigned to it are executed. The number is player-specific (valid for this player only).
PARAMS:num_0:Number of the first scriptable material in the range from 0 to the total number of scriptable materials. | num_1:Number of the second scriptable material in the range from 0 to the total number of scriptable materials.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.clearScriptableMaterials
DESC:Clears all scriptable materials attached to the player.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setMainPlayer(bool)
DESC:Sets a player as a main player.
PARAMS:player:true to set the player as the main player, false to unset it.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.isMainPlayer const
DESC:Checks if the player is a main player.
RETURNS:true if the player is a main player; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setListener(bool)
DESC:Sets the player as the listener.
PARAMS:listener:true to set the player as the listener, false to unset it.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.isListener const
DESC:Checks if the player is a listener.
RETURNS:true if the player is a listener; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getDirectionFromMainWindow(Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Math.Vec3,int,int) const
DESC:Casts the ray to a certain position on the screen and returns coordinates of the start (p0) and end (p1) points of the ray relative to the current main window.
PARAMS:p0:Start coordinates of the ray. | p1:End coordinates of the ray. | mouse_x:X-coordinate of the mouse position in world coordinates. | mouse_y:Y-coordinate of the mouse position in world coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getDirectionFromMainWindow(int,int) const
DESC:Casts the ray to a certain position on the screen and returns a vector in the direction of this position relative to the current main window.
PARAMS:mouse_x:X-coordinate of the mouse position in world coordinates. | mouse_y:Y-coordinate of the mouse position in world coordinates.
RETURNS:Vector coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getDirectionFromWindow(Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Math.Vec3,int,int,Unigine.Ptr{EngineWindowViewport}) const
DESC:Casts the ray to a certain position on the screen and returns coordinates of the start (p0) and end (p1) points of the ray relative to the specified window viewport.
PARAMS:p0:Start coordinates of the ray. | p1:End coordinates of the ray. | mouse_x:X-coordinate of the mouse position in world coordinates. | mouse_y:Y-coordinate of the mouse position in world coordinates. | window:Window viewport relative to which the directon is returned.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getDirectionFromWindow(int,int,Unigine.Ptr{EngineWindowViewport}) const
DESC:Casts the ray to a certain position on the screen and returns a vector in the direction of this position relative to the specified window viewport.
PARAMS:mouse_x:X-coordinate of the mouse position in world coordinates. | mouse_y:Y-coordinate of the mouse position in world coordinates. | window:Window viewport relative to which the directon is returned.
RETURNS:Vector coordinates.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getProjectionFromMainWindow(int,int,int,int) const
DESC:Creates a projection matrix out of 2 screen positions relative to the current main window. This is required for the frame selection.
PARAMS:x0:X-coordinate of the first screen position. | y0:Y-coordinate of the first screen position. | x1:X-coordinate of the second screen position. | y1:Y-coordinate of the second screen position.
RETURNS:Projection matrix.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getProjectionFromWindow(int,int,int,int,Unigine.Ptr{EngineWindowViewport}) const
DESC:Creates a projection matrix out of 2 screen positions relative to the specified window viewport. This is required for the frame selection.
PARAMS:x0:X-coordinate of the first screen position. | y0:Y-coordinate of the first screen position. | x1:X-coordinate of the second screen position. | y1:Y-coordinate of the second screen position. | window:Window viewport relative to which the projection is returned.
RETURNS:Projection matrix.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getMainWindowPosition(int,int,Unigine.Math.Vec3) const
DESC:Projects the point in world coordinates relative to the main window. The coordinates are written into the first 2 variables passed to the method (in pixels).
PARAMS:x:X-coordinate of the screen position (in pixels). | y:Y-coordinate of the screen position (in pixels). | point:Point coordinates.
RETURNS:1 if the point has been projected successfully; otherwise, 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getWindowPosition(int,int,Unigine.Math.Vec3,Unigine.Ptr{EngineWindowViewport}) const
DESC:Projects the point in world coordinates relative to the specified window viewport. The coordinates are written into the first 2 variables passed to the method (in pixels).
PARAMS:x:X-coordinate of the screen position (in pixels). | y:Y-coordinate of the screen position (in pixels). | point:Point coordinates. | window:Window viewport relative to which the projection is returned.
RETURNS:1 if the point has been projected successfully; otherwise, 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setProjectionMode(Camera::PROJECTION_MODE)
DESC:Sets the projection mode: orthographic or perspective.
PARAMS:mode:The projection mode, PROJECTION_MODE_ORTHOGRAPHIC for the orthographic mode; PROJECTION_MODE_PERSPECTIVE for the perspective mode.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getProjectionMode const
DESC:Returns the current projection mode: orthographic or perspective.
RETURNS:The projection mode, PROJECTION_MODE_ORTHOGRAPHIC for the orthographic mode; PROJECTION_MODE_PERSPECTIVE for the perspective mode.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.setOrthoHeight(float)
DESC:Sets the height of the camera with the orthographic projection mode enabled.
PARAMS:height:The orthographic camera height.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Player.getOrthoHeight const
DESC:Returns the current height of the camera with the orthographic projection mode enabled.
RETURNS:The orthographic camera height.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.#ctor
DESC:Constructor. Creates a new actor with default properties.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.setAcceleration(float)
DESC:Sets an acceleration of the actor.
PARAMS:acceleration:New acceleration in units per second squared. If a negative value is provided, 0 will be used instead.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getAcceleration const
DESC:Returns the current acceleration of the actor.
RETURNS:Acceleration in units per second squared.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getBody const
DESC:Returns a rigid body, if the body is simulated physically (isPhysical(1)); otherwise a dummy body will be returned (isPhysical(0)).
RETURNS:Actor body.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.setCeiling(int)
DESC:Sets a value indicating if the actor touches the ceiling surface with its head.
PARAMS:ceiling:1 to indicate that an actor touches the ceiling; otherwise, 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getCeiling const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if the actor touches the ceiling surface with its head.
RETURNS:1 if the actor touches the ceiling; otherwise, 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.setCollision(int)
DESC:Sets a value indicating if collisions with a player's capsule should be taken into account. This method is valid only in case setPhysical() is set to 0 and does not handle collisions automatically.
PARAMS:collision:1 to enable collisions, 0 not to handle collisions with the actor.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getCollision const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if collisions with a player's capsule should be taken into account. This method is valid only in case setPhysical() is set to 0 and does not handle collisions automatically.
RETURNS:1 if collisions are taken into account; otherwise, 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.setCollisionHeight(float)
DESC:Sets a height of actor's capsule.
PARAMS:height:New height in units. If a negative value is provided, 0 will be used instead.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getCollisionHeight const
DESC:Returns the height of actor's capsule.
RETURNS:Height in units.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.setCollisionMask(int)
DESC:Sets a collision mask for the actor. Two objects collide, if they both have matching masks (i.e. at least one bit matches).
PARAMS:mask:An integer value, each bit of which is used to set a bit mask.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getCollisionMask const
DESC:Returns the collision mask of the actor. Two objects collide, if they both have matching masks (i.e. at least one bit matches).
RETURNS:An integer value, each bit of which is used to set a bit mask.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.setCollisionRadius(float)
DESC:Sets a radius of actor's capsule.
PARAMS:radius:New radius in units. If a negative value is provided, 0 will be used instead.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getCollisionRadius const
DESC:Returns the radius of actor's capsule.
RETURNS:Radius in units.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getContactDepth(int) const
DESC:Returns penetration depth by the given contact.
PARAMS:contact:Contact number.
RETURNS:Penetration depth.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getContactNormal(int) const
DESC:Returns a normal of the contact point, in world coordinates.
PARAMS:contact:Contact number.
RETURNS:Normal of the contact point.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getContactObject(int) const
DESC:Returns an object participating in the contact with the player (used for collisions with physical object).
PARAMS:contact:Contact number.
RETURNS:Object in contact.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getContactPoint(int) const
DESC:Returns world coordinates of the contact point.
PARAMS:contact:Contact number.
RETURNS:Contact point.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getContactShape(int) const
DESC:Returns a shape that collided with the player's capsule.
PARAMS:num:Contact number.
RETURNS:Shape in contact.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getContactSurface(int) const
DESC:Returns the surface of the current object, which is in contact (used for collisions with non-physical object).
PARAMS:contact:Contact number.
RETURNS:Surface number.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.setDamping(float)
DESC:Sets actor's velocity damping with the time.
PARAMS:damping:New velocity damping. If a negative value is provided, 0 will be used instead.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getDamping const
DESC:Returns actor's velocity damping with the time.
RETURNS:Velocity damping.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.setGround(int)
DESC:Sets a flag indicating that the actor currently stands on the ground surface. This flag is used to set actor state, i.e. play the corresponding skinned animation of standing/walking instead of being in the air.
PARAMS:ground:1 to indicate that the actor is on the ground; otherwise, 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getGround const
DESC:Returns a flag indicating if the actor currently stands on the ground surface. This flag is used to determine the actor state, i.e. play the corresponding skinned animation of standing/walking instead of being in the air.
RETURNS:1 if the actor is on the ground; otherwise, 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.setPhysicsIntersectionMask(int)
DESC:Sets a physics intersection mask for a player (masks are considered matching if at least one bit matches).
PARAMS:mask:An integer value, each bit of which is used to set a bit mask.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getPhysicsIntersectionMask const
DESC:Returns the current physics intersection mask for a player (masks are considered matching if at least one bit matches).
RETURNS:An integer value, each bit of which is used to set a bit mask.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.setJumping(float)
DESC:Sets a jumping coefficient. The greater the value, the higher the actor jumps.
PARAMS:jumping:Jumping coefficient. If a negative value is provided, 0 will be used instead.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getJumping const
DESC:Returns the current jumping coefficient.
RETURNS:Jumping coefficient.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.setMaxFriction(float)
DESC:Sets a friction value for the actor that is used when the actor doesn't move, i.e. stands still on the ground. See also setMinFriction().
PARAMS:friction:Friction value. If a negative value is provided, 0 will be used instead.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getMaxFriction const
DESC:Returns the friction value set for the actor that is used when the actor doesn't move, i.e. stands still on the ground. See also getMinFriction().
RETURNS:Friction value.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.setMaxThetaAngle(float)
DESC:Sets the maximum theta angle (zenith angle, also known as pitch angle) that determines how far downward the player can look.
PARAMS:angle:New maximum angle in degrees in range [0;90]. The higher the value, the further down the player can look.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getMaxThetaAngle const
DESC:Returns the maximum theta angle (zenith angle, also known as pitch angle) that determines how far downward the player can look. The higher the value, the further down the player can look.
RETURNS:Angle in degrees.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.setMaxVelocity(float)
DESC:Sets the velocity of the actor, which is used while the actor runs.
PARAMS:velocity:New velocity in units per second. If a negative value is provided, 0 will be used instead.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getMaxVelocity const
DESC:Returns the velocity of the actor, which is used while the actor runs.
RETURNS:Velocity in units per second.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.setMinFriction(float)
DESC:Sets a friction value for the actor that is used when the actor walks upon the ground. See also setMaxFriction().
PARAMS:friction:Friction value. If a negative value is provided, 0 will be used instead.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getMinFriction const
DESC:Returns the friction value set for the actor that is used when the actor walks upon the ground. See also getMaxFriction().
RETURNS:Friction value.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.setMinThetaAngle(float)
DESC:Sets the minimum theta angle (zenith angle, also known as pitch angle) that determines how far upward the player can look.
PARAMS:angle:New minimum angle in degrees in range [-90;0]. The lower the value, the further up the player can look.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getMinThetaAngle const
DESC:Returns the minimum theta angle (zenith angle, also known as pitch angle) that determines how far upward the player can look. The lower the value, the further up the player can look.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.setPhysical(bool)
DESC:Sets a value indicating whether the actor should interact with the environment as a physical object or not (enables or disables its rigid body). If disabled, collisions can be handled using setCollision() method.
PARAMS:physical:Physical flag: true to enable rigid body model, false to disable it.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.isPhysical const
DESC:Returns a value indicating whether the actor interacts with the environment as a physical object or not.
RETURNS:Physical flag: true if rigid body model is enabled; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.setPhysicalMask(int)
DESC:Sets the bit mask for interaction with physicals. Two objects interact, if they both have matching masks (i.e. at least one bit matches).
PARAMS:mask:An integer value, each bit of which is used to set a bit mask.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getPhysicalMask const
DESC:Returns the bit mask for interaction with physicals. Two objects interact, if they both have matching masks (i.e. at least one bit matches).
RETURNS:An integer value, each bit of which is used to set a bit mask.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.setPhysicalMass(float)
DESC:Sets a mass of the actor. If g (Earth's gravity) equals to 9.8 m/s2, and 1 unit equals to 1 meter, the mass is measured in kilograms.
PARAMS:mass:New mass value. If a negative value is provided, 0 will be used instead.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getPhysicalMass const
DESC:Returns the current mass of the actor. If g (Earth's gravity) equals to 9.8 m/s2, and 1 unit equals to 1 meter, the mass is measured in kilograms.
RETURNS:Mass value.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getShape const

-

-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getStateTime(int) const

ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.setThetaAngle(float)
DESC:Sets the theta angle of the player (zenith angle, also known as pitch angle). This angle determines the vertical viewing direction, i.e. upward and downward. The value will be clamped between the minimum and the maximum theta angle.
PARAMS:angle:New angle in degrees in range [-90;90]. If a positive value is specified, the player will look upwards; if a negative value is specified, the player will look downwards.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.PlayerActor.getThetaAngle const
DESC:Returns the theta angle (zenith angle, also known as pitch angle). This angle determines the vertical viewing direction, i.e. upwards or downwards. If a positive value is returned, the player looks upwards; if a negative value is returned, the player looks downwards. The value is clamped between the minimum and the maximum theta angle.
RETURNS:Angle in degrees.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Plugin.get_order
DESC:Returns the execution order of the plugin. Each plugin has its execution order, which determines the sequence in which plugin’s functions (update / postUpdate / render / shutdown) will be executed. The only exception is the init function as it is called just after loading the plugin. Remember, when writing your own plugin, that requires interaction with other ones, specifying correct order value is required to avoid issues and ensure proper execution sequence. If in your case the order doesn't matter, set the default 0 value.
RETURNS:Plugin execution order.

PARAMS:size:Box size along the X, Y and Z axes.
RETURNS:ObjectMeshDynamic instance.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Primitives.createCapsule(float,float,int,int)
DESC:Creates a dynamic mesh in a form of a capsule.
PARAMS:radius:Capsule radius. | height:Capsule height. | stacks:Number of stacks that divide the capsule radially. | slices:Number of slices that divide the capsule horizontally.
RETURNS:ObjectMeshDynamic instance.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Primitives.createCylinder(float,float,int,int)
DESC:Creates a dynamic mesh in a form of a cylinder.
PARAMS:radius:Cylinder radius. | height:Cylinder height. | stacks:Number of stacks that divide the cylinder radially. | slices:Number of slices that divide the cylinder horizontally.
RETURNS:ObjectMeshDynamic instance.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Primitives.createDodecahedron(float)
DESC:Creates a dynamic mesh in a form of a dodecahedron.
PARAMS:radius:Dodecahedron radius.
RETURNS:ObjectMeshDynamic instance.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Primitives.createIcosahedron(float)
DESC:Creates a dynamic mesh in a form of an icosahedron.
PARAMS:radius:Icosahedron radius.
RETURNS:ObjectMeshDynamic instance.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Primitives.createPlane(float,float,float)
DESC:Creates a dynamic mesh in a form of a plane. It is divided into equal squares whose size is defined by the given step.
PARAMS:width:Plane width. | height:Plane height. | step:Step of surface subdivision (vertical and horizontal).
RETURNS:ObjectMeshDynamic instance.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Primitives.createPrism(float,float,float,int)
DESC:Creates a dynamic mesh in a form of a prism.
PARAMS:size_0:Radius of the circle circumscribed about the top prism base. | size_1:Radius of the circle circumscribed about the bottom prism base. | height:Height of the prism. | sides:Number of the prism faces.
RETURNS:ObjectMeshDynamic instance.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Primitives.createSphere(float,int,int)
DESC:Creates a dynamic mesh in a form of a sphere.
PARAMS:radius:Sphere radius. | stacks:Number of stacks that divide the sphere radially. | slices:Number of slices that divide the sphere horizontally.
RETURNS:ObjectMeshDynamic instance.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Primitives.addBoxSurface(Unigine.Ptr{ObjectMeshDynamic},Unigine.Math.vec3,Unigine.Math.mat4)
DESC:Appends a box of the specified size to ObjectMeshDynamic.
PARAMS:object:ObjectMeshDynamic instance. | size:Box size along the X, Y and Z axes. | transform:Box transformation matrix.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Primitives.addCapsuleSurface(Unigine.Ptr{ObjectMeshDynamic},float,float,Unigine.Math.mat4,int,int)
DESC:Appends a capsule of the specified size to ObjectMeshDynamic. The stacks and slices specify the surface's subdivision.
PARAMS:object:ObjectMeshDynamic instance. | radius:Capsule radius. | height:Capsule height along the central axis. | transform:Capsule transformation matrix. | stacks:Number of stacks that divide the capsule radially. | slices:Number of slices that divide the capsule horizontally.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Primitives.addCylinderSurface(Unigine.Ptr{ObjectMeshDynamic},float,float,Unigine.Math.mat4,int,int)
DESC:Appends a cylinder of the specified size to ObjectMeshDynamic. The stacks and slices specify the surface's subdivision.
PARAMS:object:ObjectMeshDynamic instance. | radius:Cylinder radius. | height:Cylinder height. | transform:Cylinder transformation matrix. | stacks:Number of stacks that divide the cylinder radially. | slices:Number of slices that divide the cylinder horizontally.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Primitives.addDodecahedronSurface(Unigine.Ptr{ObjectMeshDynamic},float,Unigine.Math.mat4)
DESC:Appends a dodecahedron (a polyhedron with twelve flat faces) of the specified size to ObjectMeshDynamic.
PARAMS:object:ObjectMeshDynamic instance. | radius:Dodecahedron radius. | transform:Transformation matrix.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Primitives.addIcosahedronSurface(Unigine.Ptr{ObjectMeshDynamic},float,Unigine.Math.mat4)
DESC:Appends a icosahedron (a polyhedron with twenty flat faces) of the specified size to ObjectMeshDynamic.
PARAMS:object:ObjectMeshDynamic instance. | radius:Icosahedron radius. | transform:Transformation matrix.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Primitives.addPlaneSurface(Unigine.Ptr{ObjectMeshDynamic},float,float,float,Unigine.Math.mat4)
DESC:Appends a plane surface to the dynamic mesh. The plane is divided into equal squares, size of which is defined by the given step.
PARAMS:object:ObjectMeshDynamic instance. | width:Width of the plane. | height:Height of the plane. | step:Step of surface subdivision (vertical and horizontal). | transform:Plane transformation matrix.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Primitives.addPrismSurface(Unigine.Ptr{ObjectMeshDynamic},float,float,float,Unigine.Math.mat4,int)
DESC:Appends a prism to the dynamic mesh.
PARAMS:object:ObjectMeshDynamic instance. | size_0:Radius of the circle circumscribed about the top prism base. | size_1:Radius of the circle circumscribed about the bottom prism base. | height:Dimension of the prism's central axis. | transform:Prism transformation matrix. | sides:Number of the prism faces.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Primitives.addSphereSurface(Unigine.Ptr{ObjectMeshDynamic},float,Unigine.Math.mat4,int,int)
DESC:Appends a sphere surface to the dynamic mesh. The stacks and slices specify the surface's subdivision.
PARAMS:object:ObjectMeshDynamic instance. | radius:Sphere radius. | transform:Transformation matrix. | stacks:Number of stacks that divide the sphere radially. | slices:Number of slices that divide the sphere horizontally.

FILE:UnigineProfiler.xml
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Profiler.setValue(char,char,int,int,float)
DESC:Updates settings of the integer counter.
PARAMS:name:Name of the counter. | units:Counter units. | value:Value of the counter. | max_value:Counter maximum value. | arg5:Color of the graph. Pass NULL if no graph is required.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Profiler.setValue(char,char,float,float,float)
DESC:Updates settings of the float counter.
PARAMS:name:Name of the counter. | units:Counter units. | value:Value of the counter. | max_value:Counter maximum value. | arg5:Color of the graph. Pass NULL if no graph is required.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Profiler.getValue(char) const
DESC:Returns a value of the specified counter.
PARAMS:name:The name of the counter.
RETURNS:Value of the counter in milliseconds.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Profiler.begin(char,Unigine.Math.vec4) const
DESC:Starts a counter with a given name and shows a colored graph (if the show_profiler 1 console variable is set). The counter shows user how many millisecods have been spent for the operation that is performed between the begin() and the end() functions.
PARAMS:name:Name of the counter. | color:Color of the graph.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Profiler.begin(char) const
DESC:Starts a counter with a given name. The counter shows user how many millisecods have been spent for the operation that is performed between the begin() and the end() functions.
PARAMS:name:Name of the counter.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Profiler.end const
DESC:Stops the last activated counter and returns its value.
RETURNS:Value of the counter in milliseconds.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Profiler.beginMicro(char,bool) const
DESC:Starts a counter with a given name in the Microprofile only, without overloading the Performance Profiler layout. The counter shows user how many millisecods have been spent for the operation that is performed between the beginMicro() and the endMicro() functions.Each counter has an ID. Thus, several nested beginMicro() / endMicro() blocks can be created, which can't be done in the Performance Profiler.
PARAMS:name:Name of the counter. | gpu:true for the GPU counter; false — for the CPU counter. The default value is false.
RETURNS:ID of the added counter.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Profiler.endMicro(int) const
DESC:Stops a previously activated Microprofile counter with the specified ID.
PARAMS:id:Microprofile counter ID.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Profiler.initThread(char,int)
DESC:Initiates the custom thread for Microprofile calculations to avoid spikes, which otherwise are registered by Microprofile on registering a new thread. This method shall be called at the beginning of the thread and before and followed by when the thread is not required anymore.
PARAMS:name:Name of the thread displayed in Microprofile. | priority:Order (ordinal number) of the thread displayed in Microprofile.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Profiler.shutdownThread
DESC:Stops a previously activated Microprofile thread counter. This method shall be called after and before the thread ends.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Profiler.findCounter(char) const
DESC:Returns the counter number by its name.
PARAMS:name:Name of the counter.
RETURNS:Counter number in range from 0 to the total number of counters.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Profiler.getCounterName(int) const
DESC:Returns the counter name by its number.
PARAMS:num:Counter number in range from 0 to the total number of counters.
RETURNS:Name of the counter.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Profiler.getCounterText(int) const
DESC:Returns the text of the specified counter.
PARAMS:num:Counter number in range from 0 to the total number of counters.
RETURNS:Text of the counter.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Profiler.getCounterColor(int) const
DESC:Returns the color of the specified counter.
PARAMS:num:Counter number in range from 0 to the total number of counters.
RETURNS:Color of the counter.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Profiler.getCounterValue(int) const
DESC:Returns the value of the specified counter.
PARAMS:num:Counter number in range from 0 to the total number of counters.
RETURNS:Value of the counter.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Profiler.getCounterFrame(int) const
DESC:Returns the frame of the specified counter.
PARAMS:num:Counter number in range from 0 to the total number of counters.
RETURNS:Frame of the counter.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Profiler.isCounterActive(int) const
DESC:Returns the value indicating if the specified counter is active.
PARAMS:num:Counter number in range from 0 to the total number of counters.
RETURNS:true if the counter is active; otherwise false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Profiler.isCounterSeparator(int) const
DESC:Returns the value indicating if a separator is placed after the specified counter.
PARAMS:num:Counter number in range from 0 to the total number of counters.
RETURNS:true if the separator is placed; otherwise false.

-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.isParent(char) const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if the property with the given name is a parent of this property. Suppose we have the following two manual properties in our project: The following code will return 1 as the my_prop property is the parent of the my_prop_0 property:
PARAMS:name:Parent property name.
RETURNS:true if the property with the given name is a parent of this property; otherwise, false.
-

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.setParent(Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Property},bool)
DESC:Sets the given property as the parent for this property and saves the parameter values of the property (if the corresponding flag is set). The method is not available for manual and non-editable properties.
PARAMS:property:Property to be set as the parent for this property. | save_all_values:Flag indicating if parameter values of the property will be saved after reparenting.
RETURNS:1 if the given property was successfully set as the parent for this property; otherwise, 0.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.clone
DESC:Clones the property. The cloned property won't have a name, a path and won't be displayed in the properties hierarchy.
RETURNS:Cloned property smart pointer.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.clone(char,char)
DESC:Clones the property and assigns the specified name and path to the clone. The cloned property will be saved to the specified path on saveProperties() call. This method may be used, for example, to create a property missed during project's migration.
PARAMS:name:Cloned property name. | path:Path to save the cloned property.
RETURNS:Cloned property smart pointer.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.clone(char,char,Unigine.UGUID)
DESC:Clones the property and assigns the specified name, GUID and path to the clone. The cloned property will be saved to the specified path on saveProperties() call. This method may be used, for example, to create a property missed during project's migration.
PARAMS:name:Cloned property name. | path:Path to save the cloned property. | guid:Cloned property GUID.
RETURNS:Cloned property smart pointer.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.clone(char)
DESC:Clones the property.
PARAMS:name:Cloned property name.
RETURNS:Cloned property smart pointer.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.inherit
DESC:Inherits a new property from this one. The inherited property will be empty: it won't have a name, a path and won't be displayed in the properties hierarchy.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.inherit(char)

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.inherit(char,char)

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.inherit(char,char,Unigine.UGUID)

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.loadXml(Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Xml})

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.loadWorld(Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Xml})
DESC:Loads data of the current property (all its options, states and parameters) from the given instance of the Xml class.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.canSaveInFile const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if the property can be saved to a file. For example, this function will return 0 for an internal or manual property.

-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.saveState(Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Stream}) const
DESC:Saves data of the current property (all its parameters) into a binary stream. Example using saveState() and restoreState() methods:
PARAMS:stream:Stream into which the property data will be saved.
RETURNS:true if the property data is saved successfully; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.restoreState(Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Stream},int)
DESC:Restores the data of the property (all its parameters) from a binary stream in the specified mode. Example using saveState() and restoreState() methods:
PARAMS:stream:Stream in which the saved property parameter data is stored. | restore_mode:Restore mode. One of the Property::RESTORE_MODE_* values. The default value is Property::RESTORE_MODE_REPLACE.
RETURNS:true on success; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.save
DESC:Saves the property data to the file specified by the setFilePath() function. This method is not available for manual and internal properties.
RETURNS:true if the property data is saved successfully; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.save(char)
DESC:Saves the property data to the specified *.prop file.This method is not available for manual properties.
PARAMS:path:Path to the *.prop file to save the property data to.
RETURNS:true if the property data is saved successfully; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.saveXml(Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Xml}) const
DESC:Saves data of the property (all its parameters) to the given instance of the Xml class. This method is not available for manual properties.
PARAMS:xml:Xml class instance into which the property data will be saved.
RETURNS:true if the property data is saved successfully; otherwise, false.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.saveWorld(Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Xml},int) const
DESC:Saves data of the current property (all its parameters) into the given instance of the Xml class.
PARAMS:xml:Xml class instance into which the property data will be saved. | force:A value indicating if forced saving of property data is used: 1 to enable forced saving, 0 to disable it.
RETURNS:true if the property data is saved successfully; otherwise, false.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.parameterNameByType(int) const
DESC:Returns parameter type name by the type identifier specified.
PARAMS:param_type:Parameter type identifier, one of the PARAMETER_* variables.
RETURNS:Parameter type name.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.getParameterPtr(char)
DESC:Returns a property parameter by its name.
PARAMS:name:Property parameter name.
RETURNS:Property parameter smart pointer.This method never returns nullptr, regardless of whether a parameter with the specified name exists or not. It only displays an error message in the console in case of a non-existing parameter. To check if such parameter really exists, use the PropertyParameter.isExist() method. For example: // getting some property named "my_property"PropertyPtr pProperty = Properties::findManualProperty("my_property");// trying to get a property parameter named "some_parameter"PropertyParameterPtr param = pProperty->getParameterPtr("some_parameter");// checking if such parameter exists and displaying a messageif (param->isExist())Log::message("Specified property parameter exists!\n");elseLog::message("No such parameter!\n");
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.getParameterPtr(int)
DESC:Returns a property parameter by its ID.
PARAMS:id:Property parameter ID.
RETURNS:Property parameter smart pointer.This method never returns nullptr, regardless of whether a parameter with the specified ID exists or not. It only displays an error message in the console in case of a non-existing parameter. To check if such parameter really exists, use the PropertyParameter.isExist() method. For example: // getting some property named "my_property"PropertyPtr pProperty = Properties::findManualProperty("my_property");// trying to get a property parameter having the ID=30PropertyParameterPtr param = pProperty->getParameterPtr(30);// checking if such parameter exists and displaying a messageif (param->isExist())Log::message("Property parameter with the specified ID exists!\n");elseLog::message("No such parameter!\n");
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Property.findStruct(char) const
DESC:Returns the number of the structure with the specified name.

PARAMS:guid:GUID of the property whose parent is to be changed. | new_parent:GUID of the property to be set as a new parent. | save_all_values:Flag indicating if parameter values of the specified property will be saved after reparenting.
RETURNS:true if the parent for the property is changed successfully; otherwise, false.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Properties.reloadProperties

DESC:Saves all properties that can be saved to corresponding *.prop files. This method will save only the properties that: are not manual are editable have a name (not internal) have a path
RETURNS:1 if all properties are saved successfully; otherwise, 0.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.BakeLighting.bake(Unigine.Vector{Unigine.Ptr{LightVoxelProbe},int,Unigine.VectorAllocator},Unigine.Vector{Unigine.Ptr{LightEnvironmentProbe},int,Unigine.VectorAllocator},Unigine.Vector{Unigine.Ptr{Light},int,Unigine.VectorAllocator},Unigine.Vector{Unigine.Ptr{ObjectMeshStatic},int,Unigine.VectorAllocator},Unigine.Vector{int,int,Unigine.VectorAllocator})
DESC:Starts the process of light baking for all voxel and environment probes, shadow baking for light sources in static light mode and lightmaps baking for surfaces of Mesh Static objects in the given list.
PARAMS:voxel_lights:List of voxel probes for which the process of light baking is to be performed. The order of nodes added for baking is not important. | env_lights:List of environment probes for which the process of light baking is to be performed. The order of nodes added for baking is not important. | shadow_lights:List of light sources in static light mode for which the process of shadow baking is to be performed. The order of lights added for baking is not important. | objects:List of Mesh Static objects for which the process of lightmaps baking is to be performed. | surfaces:List of surfaces of Mesh Static objects for which the process of lightmaps baking is to be performed.The number of objects and surfaces added for baking must be equal.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.BakeLighting.bakeAll(bool,bool,bool,bool)

PARAMS:voxel_probes:true to enable light baking for voxel probes; otherwise, false. | env_probes:true to enable light baking for environment probes; otherwise, false. | shadow:true to enable shadow baking for light sources in static light mode; otherwise, false. | lightmap:true to enable lightmaps baking for surfaces of Mesh Static objects; otherwise, false.

ENTRY:F:Unigine.BakeLighting.LIGHTMAP_QUALITY_LOW

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Render.addScriptableMaterial(Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Material})
DESC:Adds a new global scriptable material. To apply a scriptable material per-camera or per-player, use the addScriptableMaterial() method of the Camera class or the same method of the Player class respectively. The order of execution for scripts assigned to scriptable materials is defined by material's number in the list of materials applied globally. Scriptable materials applied globally have their expressions executed before the ones that are applied per-camera or per-player.
PARAMS:material:Scriptable material to be applied globally.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Render.insertScriptableMaterial(int,Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Material})
DESC:Inserts a new global scriptable material to the list of globally applied scriptable materials. To apply a scriptable material per-camera or per-player, use the insertScriptableMaterial() method of the Camera class or the same method of the Player class respectively. The order of execution for scripts assigned to scriptable materials is defined by material's number in the list of materials applied globally. Scriptable materials applied globally have their expressions executed before the ones that are applied per-camera or per-player.
PARAMS:num:Position at which a new scriptable material is to be inserted. | material:Scriptable material to be inserted into the list of globally applied scriptable materials.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Render.removeScriptableMaterial(int)
DESC:Removes the global scriptable material with the specified number.
PARAMS:num:Scriptable material number in the range from 0 to the total number of scriptable materials.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Render.findScriptableMaterial(Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Material}) const
DESC:Returns the number of the specified scriptable material applied globally. This number determines the order in which the assigned expressions are executed. Scriptable materials applied globally have their expressions executed before the ones that are applied per-camera or per-player.
PARAMS:material:Scriptable material for which a number is to be found.
RETURNS:Scriptable material number in the range from 0 to the total number of scriptable materials, or -1 if the specified material was not found.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Render.setScriptableMaterial(int,Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Material})
DESC:Replaces the scriptable material with the specified number with the new scriptable material specified. The number of material determines the order in which the expressions assigned to it are executed. Scriptable materials applied globally have their expressions executed before the ones that are applied per-camera or per-player.
PARAMS:num:Scriptable material number in the range from 0 to the total number of scriptable materials. | material:New scriptable material to replace the one with the specified number.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Render.getScriptableMaterial(int) const
DESC:Returns a scriptable material applied globally by its number.
PARAMS:num:Scriptable material number in the range from 0 to the total number of scriptable materials.
RETURNS:Scriptable material applied globally with the specified number.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Render.setScriptableMaterialEnabled(int,bool)
DESC:Enables or disables the scriptable material with the specified number. When a material is disabled (inactive), the scripts attached to it are not executed.
PARAMS:num:Scriptable material number in the range from 0 to the total number of scriptable materials. | enabled:1 to enable the scriptable material with the specified number, 0 to disable it.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Render.getScriptableMaterialEnabled(int) const
DESC:Returns a value indicating if the scriptable material with the specified number is enabled (active). When a material is disabled (inactive), the scripts attached to it are not executed.
PARAMS:num:Scriptable material number in the range from 0 to the total number of scriptable materials.
RETURNS:1 if the scriptable material with the specified number is enabled; otherwise, 0.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Render.swapScriptableMaterials(int,int)
DESC:Swaps two scriptable materials with specified numbers. The number of material determines the order in which the expressions assigned to it are executed. Scriptable materials applied globally have their expressions executed before the ones that are applied per-camera or per-player.
PARAMS:num_0:Number of the first scriptable material in the range from 0 to the total number of scriptable materials. | num_1:Number of the second scriptable material in the range from 0 to the total number of scriptable materials.
-
ENTRY:M:Unigine.Render.clearScriptableMaterials
DESC:Clears all global scriptable materials.
-

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Render.getTemporaryTexture(int,int,int,int,int,int,char,Render::TEXTURE_ACCESSORY,Render::TEXTURE_LIFETIME,bool)
DESC:Allocates a temporary render texture with the specified width, height, depth, format, flags, and type. This function can be used when you need a quick render texture to perform some temporary calculations. Release it using releaseTemporaryTexture() as soon as you're done with it, so another call can start reusing it, if necessary. In any case, such texture shall be released automatically in the next frame. UNIGINE keeps an internal pool of temporary render textures, so a call to this method most often just returns an already created one (if the size and format match). These temporary textures are actually destroyed when they aren't used for a couple of frames. If you are doing a series of post-processing "blits", it's best for performance to get and release a temporary render texture for each blit, instead of getting one or two render textures upfront and reusing them. You can't rely on any particular contents of a temporary texture obtained from this function: it might be garbage, or it might be cleared to some color, depending on the platform. It also automatically gives names to resources, which can be used for identification in debug.
PARAMS:width:Width of the texture, in pixels. | height:Height of the texture, in pixels. | depth:Depth of the texture, in pixels. | format:Texture format: one of the Texture::FORMAT_* values. | flags:Texture flags. | type:Texture type (2D, 3D, Cube, etc.): one of the Texture::TEXTURE_* values. | name:Name to be used for this temporary texture (optional). If not specified, a new name for it will be generated automatically. | accessory:Texture render sequence accessory type. One of the TEXTURE_ACCESSORY_* values. | lifetime:Texture lifetime (the texture will be released automatically when its lifetime expires, if the auto_release flag is set). One of the TEXTURE_LIFETIME* values. | auto_release:true to enable automatic release of the temporary texture by its lifetime, false to release it manually.
RETURNS:Temporary texture.
-

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Render.getTemporaryOldTexture(Unigine.Ptr{Unigine.Material},int,int,int,int,int,int,int,char,Render::TEXTURE_ACCESSORY)
DESC:Allocates a temporary render texture from the previous frame with the specified width, height, depth, format, flags, and accessory type. This function can be used when you need a quick render texture to perform some temporary calculations. This texture doesn't require to be released. UNIGINE keeps an internal pool of temporary render textures, so a call to this method most often just returns an already created one (if the size and format match). These temporary textures are actually destroyed when they aren't used for a couple of frames. If you are doing a series of post-processing "blits", it's best for performance to get and release a temporary render texture for each blit, instead of getting one or two render textures upfront and reusing them. You can't rely on any particular contents of a temporary texture obtained from this function: it might be garbage, or it might be cleared to some color, depending on the platform. It also automatically gives names to resources, which can be used for identification in debug.
PARAMS:mat:Material that will use the texture with the specified ID. | texture_id:Texture ID set by the user, value in the range [0, 255]. | width:Width of the texture, in pixels. | height:Height of the texture, in pixels. | depth:Depth of the texture, in pixels. | format:Texture format: one of the Texture::FORMAT_* values. | flags:Texture flags. | type:Texture type (2D, 3D, Cube, etc.): one of the Texture::TEXTURE_* values. | name:Name to be used for this temporary texture (optional). | accessory:Texture render sequence accessory type. One of the TEXTURE_ACCESSORY_* values.
RETURNS:Temporary texture from the previous frame.

If you are doing a series of post-processing "blits", it's best for performance to get and release a temporary render texture for each blit, instead of getting one or two render textures upfront and reusing them. You can't rely on any particular contents of a temporary texture obtained from this function: it might be garbage, or it might be cleared to some color, depending on the platform. It also automatically gives names to resources, which can be used for identification in debug.
PARAMS:mat:Material that will use the texture with the specified ID. | texture_id:Texture ID set by the user, value in the range [0, 255]. | width:Width of the texture, in pixels. | height:Height of the texture, in pixels. | format:Texture format: one of the Texture::FORMAT_* values. | flags:Texture flags. | accessory:Texture render sequence accessory type. One of the TEXTURE_ACCESSORY_* values.
RETURNS:Temporary 2D texture from the previous frame.

ENTRY:M:Unigine.Render.getTemporaryRenderTarget
DESC:Allocates a temporary render target. This function can be used when you need a quick render target to perform some temporary calculations. Release it using releaseTemporaryRenderTarget() as soon as you're done with it, so another call can start reusing it if necessary. In any case such render target shall be released automatically in the next frame. UNIGINE keeps an internal pool of temporary render targets, so a call to this method most often just returns an already created one (if the size and format matches). These temporary render targets are actually destroyed when they aren't used for a couple of frames. If you are doing a series of post-processing "blits", it's best for performance to get and release a temporary render targets for each blit, instead of getting one or two render targets upfront and reusing them. You can't depend on any particular contents of a temporary render target obtained from this function: it might be garbage, or it might be cleared to some color, depending on the platform.
RETURNS:Temporary render target.
-
